headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding,
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding, among other things, the company's financial objectives and forecasts. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and other factors that are described and detailed in the company's SEC filings. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Matt Farrell, Chief Executive Officer of Church & Dwight. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. It's always a pleasure to talk to you about our business. I'll start with a brief review of our first quarter results, which you read about in this morning's press release. I'll then direct the rest of my comments towards our categ
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. It's always a pleasure to talk to you about our business. I'll start with a brief review of our first quarter results, which you read about in this morning's press release. I'll then direct the rest of my comments towards our categories. I'm going to turn the call over to Rick Dierker when I'm done. Rick will comment on each business that's domestic, international and Specialty Products and also review the outlook for Q2 and for the full year. When Rick is finished, I'll get back on and we'll open the call up to questions. 
So here are the highlights. In short, Q1 was a terrific quarter for Church & Dwight. We delivered organic sales growth of 5.2% and 7.5% EPS growth, which is 10% EPS growth on a currency-neutral basis. Category growth was broad-based in that 11 of our 15 categories grew in the quarter. From a market share perspective, 6 of our 10 power brands grew share so all in these result are top-tier and consumer products. Now I'd like to provide you with some color on a few of our categories. That'll be laundry, litter, vitamins and dry shampoo. 
The laundry category is strong, growing 6.4% versus a year ago. This is the fourth quarter in a row of laundry category growth. The value segment grew 6.1% and this is the sixth consecutive quarter of value segment growth. In fact, for the last 4 quarters, value has grown on average 4.5% per quarter. The laundry category growth was driven by growth in both the unit dose and liquid segments. This value liquid segment grew at an 8% clip, driven by ARM & HAMMER liquid, which grew consumption a whopping 11% year-over-year. 
With respect to unit dose, this form now represents 15% of the laundry category. Our unit dose consumption grew 15% in the quarter. More recently, we have launched new 2 chamber unit dose products under the OxiClean and ARM & HAMMER brands. We expect these new products to contribute to future consumption growth. Most of the resets for these launches happened in late March and early April. 
Now I'd like to take a few minutes to talk about our 3 laundry brands. ARM & HAMMER has been our big franchise in laundry for many years and the ARM & HAMMER laundry share continue to grow this quarter, up 30 basis points. To illustrate the strength of the ARM & HAMMER brand, ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry has grown share year-over-year in 25 consecutive quarters. Our XTRA brand backed off commercial volumes in Q1, which improved our year-over-year profitability but resulted in our giving up 40 basis points per share. On a full-year basis, we expect XTRA next sales and [indiscernible] to be up year-over-year. 
Oxi laundry share was down 10 basis points year-over-year. As we, like others saw the impact of Persil's promotional activity. In the most recent 4-week period, we are back to a 1 share. So promotional phasing does influence shares. If we look at how OxiClean is doing in the stain fighter or additive category, OxiClean's share hit an all-time high of 40% [ph], 80% share. 
Now I'm going to turn my comments to cat litter. The clumping litter segment continued to show strong growth at 5.3%. ARM & HAMMER litter was 1 of the winners in the quarter. We continue to grow faster than the segment. Our consumption grew 6.7% behind our latest innovation, MicroGuard CLUMP & SEAL litter. Just a quick commercial. MicroGuard seals and destroys odors, and prevents future bacterial odors from forming. It's an innovative product and we are broadcasting that message on our package that 98% of consumers who have tried the product would recommend it. 
Now let's talk about vitamins. The overall VMS category continues to show steady growth, up 3%. The gummy segment of VMS grew almost 15% in Q1. And so let me break down the 15% for you. The adult gummy segment grew 23% while the kids gummy segment declined 8%. Adult gums is where we are putting our focus as it is underdeveloped and it will be the source of future growth for us. Our brand, Vitafusion, is the largest brand in the adult gummy category and was the biggest driver of the 23% adult segment category growth. The good news this quarter is that our gummy business is growing again. 
We have had wide retailer acceptance of our new adult beauty line, which hit shores -- which hit store shelves in March. So we are off to a good start this year for vitamins. The last category I want to address is dry shampoo. This category grew 26% in Q1 year-over-year. A, the category in the U.S. is nearly $100 million with the potential to be a $300 million category in the U.S. if we match the historical category growth experienced in the U.K. BATISTE is the #1 brand in the U.S. with a 17.2% share. BATISTE global net sales will cross $100 million this year, making it the #1 dry shampoo brand globally. So it's no surprise that the BATISTE brand is expected to be 1 of our fastest growing brands in the future. 
Many new products are shipping right now. I've mentioned dual chamber pods, MicroGuard glitter and the vitamin beauty line. In addition, we have the new groove condom and Riviera lubricant by TROJAN, and the new Bluetooth-enabled pregnancy test kit from FIRST RESPONSE. We feel good about our distribution, and we look forward to these products contributing to our organic growth in 2016. Our goal is to continue to focus on consumer insights, leading us to innovative new products to drive share and category growth. 
Next up is Rick to give you details on our first quarter results and the outlook for Q2 and the full year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. First quarter reported EPS was $0.86 per share compared to $0.80 in 2015, up 7.5%. The $0.86 was better than our $0.83 outlook, largely due to organic revenue beat and gross margin expansi
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. First quarter reported EPS was $0.86 per share compared to $0.80 in 2015, up 7.5%. The $0.86 was better than our $0.83 outlook, largely due to organic revenue beat and gross margin expansion beat. Netted in that $0.86 is $0.02 or 2.5% drag from currency year-over-year. Reported revenue were up 4.5% to $849 million. Organic sales were 5.2%, exceeding our Q1 outlook of approximately 2% to 3%. The organic sales beat was driven by our consumer business both domestic and international. 
Now let's review the segments. The Consumer Domestic businesses organic sales increased by 4.5%, driven by the continued success of our ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry, detergent, Vitafusion Gummy Vitamin, BATISTE dry shampoo and ARM & HAMMER CLUMP & SEAL cat litter. We now expect the full year organic sales to be approximately 3% for the Consumer Domestic business. International organic growth was up an impressive 13.3%. Now some of that was timing as orders are a little lumpy in the export business. But underlying growth was very strong at approximately 9%. Here again, we're raising our expectation for the full year. Organic growth from 4% to approximately 5% to 6% from the consumer international business. 
For Specialty Products Division, organic sales was down 2%, driven by further declines in milk pricing and a difficult comp of 11% growth a year ago. Prices have come down 10% in the last 90 days as there is an oversupply globally. And as a result, U.S. exports, which historically had been 15% plus of U.S. production, are now around 10%. We have lowered our expectations for the full year for the SPD division from up 1% to 3% to down 2%. This is a headwind that we expect to overcome for the full year and we still like this business, but we do experience these cycles from time to time. 
Turning now to gross margins. Our reported first quarter gross margin was 44.6%, an 80 basis point increase from a year ago. Q1 gross margin benefited from 3 factors: lower commodities, productivity programs and the higher-margin from acquired businesses. These factors were partially offset by foreign exchange, negative product mix and higher fixed costs associated with our new vitamin capacity in our New York facility. 
Moving to marketing. We increased marketing spend by 4.2% year-over-year. Marketing as a percent of revenue was consistent with 2015 at 10.9%. SG&A as a percentage of net sales was 12.6%, a 90 basis point increase from the prior year. This was primarily due to incremental amortization from acquisitions and the timing of management stock compensation. 
Now to operating profit. The reported operating margin for the quarter was 21.1%, which was 10 basis points lower than the prior year. Other income and expense was $6.4 million, largely $7 million of expense related to interest expense. Next is income taxes. Our effective tax rate for the quarter is 34.7%. And turning to cash. We had a strong cash flow quarter. We generated $178 million of net cash for the first quarter and $33 million increase from the same quarter a year ago. So in conclusion, the first quarter highlights include 5.2% organic, 7.5% EPS growth, which again equates to a 10% currency-neutral EPS growth. 
Turning to the second quarter outlook. We expect Q2 organic sales growth of approximately 2% to 3%, and I know a lot of you guys like to look at growth on a 2-year stacked basis. Remember for the total company, year ago, Q2 was 5% organic. So on the 2-year stacked, Q1 and Q2 were pretty similar at approximately 8%. Now if we just focus in on the Consumer Domestic business for a minute. The 2 year stacked is going from 6.1% in Q1 to almost 8% in Q2. So a lot of positive momentum continuing on. We expect marketing as a percentage of revenue to be flat year-over-year and gross margin to expand in Q2. We expect second quarter earnings per share of approximately $0.79 compared to an adjusted $0.73 per share year ago or an 8% increase year-over-year. 
And now turning to the full year. To summarize our thinking, we're raising our expectations organic sales growth from 3% to 3% or 4%. In February, we called approximately 40 basis points of gross margin expansion and we're pleased to say that now, we're calling 70 basis points of gross margin expansion -- 75. Back in February, this broke out as 70 basis points of health and commodities and productivity, offset by 30 basis points from currency headwind. The 75 basis points we expect now is 100 basis points from commodities and productivity programs, offset by a 25 basis point drag from currency. We're more optimistic about the stability of commodity pricing across the entire commodity basket for the full year than we were a quarter ago. 
Our full-year marketing expectation continues to be 12.3% of sales consistent with 2015 and prior years. Moving to SG&A. Our original expectations were 10 basis point reduction. We now expect a 25 basis point increase largely behind R&D, IT and Internet international sales force investments. Let me give you a little color on these investments. First, investing in R&D projects behind our future project portfolio. Second, investing in our international sales force, footprint, specifically in high-growth areas of our business to drive our future growth. And third, we expect higher ongoing IT infrastructure costs as we implement 2 new important systems: our spec management system for R&D and our trade management system for sales. We are positioning ourselves well for the future. 
We continue to expect the 2 basis points of operating margin expansion. Next is income tax. We now expect 34.7% for the full year. So it's a little higher than our previous outlook of 34.5%. We continue to expect $630 million of free cash flow net of approximately $65 million of CapEx for full-year 2016. This represents 125% free cash flow conversion. 
So now Matt and I will open it up for questions.

componenttext: I don't have the crystal ball to say, we're going to have mid-single digit the whole year, that's going to be a function of year-over-year comps, right? componenttext: Yes, Bill, I think that's a fair question. We talked it a little bit on our Analyst Day and we kind of talked through some of the headwind like transactional currency. But I'd say overall, we're really pleased with our gross margin expansion. We just talked about how we're going from 40 basis points to 75. So essentially, we're doubling it and that entire doubling of it is largely commodity. I think we feel more comfortable with that full-year outlook of commodities. So do we have one of the every now and then on write-offs and whatnot, that burden gross margin? Sure. But overall in general, we're really happy about doubling our gross margin outlook pretty much. And if commodities continue to stay where they're at or improve, we'll probably be talking about it again.

componenttext: Okay. And then I know this is a small one, and maybe a little nifty, but on the expense force acquisition, I think you spend $175 million for $30 million of sales. Is this sort of a massive growth separate in the business, is that why you've paid a high multiple sales?

componenttext: Yes. I think we probably got similar questions like that when we bought BATISTE back in 2011. The way to think about that, Bill, is the hair thinning category is about a $240 million category, that's mostly dominated by Topicals, brands like Grow Gain. And from our point of view, is that hair thinning can also be addressed with hair fibers. And we bought a product that we think is going to have significant growth in the future because it addresses the problem of the cosmetic fashion and not with chemicals.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about your new product. You went through some stuff pretty quickly. But can you elaborate on some of the major ideas and why you think that this is going to keep the momentum strong and if you think your market share gains can continue?
componenttext: I wanted to talk about your new product. You went through some stuff pretty quickly. But can you elaborate on some of the major ideas and why you think that this is going to keep the momentum strong and if you think your market share gains can continue?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been the leader in the litter category for many years now. If you remember, when we spoke downtown in February and we showed a chart that showed our innovations over the past 3 or 4 years. So we've clearly been the catalyst of that category. A
componenttext: Well, we've been the leader in the litter category for many years now. If you remember, when we spoke downtown in February and we showed a chart that showed our innovations over the past 3 or 4 years. So we've clearly been the catalyst of that category. And we have a winner again this year with the MicroGuard product. So we're driving growth from that category, which is a big category. And we're taking share. And we generally have a big new idea every year. So we think we can continue that in the future. With respect to laundry. As I said earlier, well, ARM & HAMMER has been quite a powerhouse for us for a long time. The new product this year is, one of them is the bioenzyme product, which has the EPA safer choice label, which is becoming more meaningful to all shoppers. So we think that's a nice new variant for us to help us continue to grow the franchise. Some of the other things I mentioned. Vitamins, what we did was we decided to shrinkwrap our products so we got beautiful new packaging, which obviously, speak out -- pops on shelf. And we think that, that is going to be a winner for us this year as well. Continuing down the line. In the TROJAN Riviera, so this a [indiscernible] can be used in the shower. So that's another consumer insight that we think is going to expand the share for TROJAN and as you know, TROJAN's share continues to grow. We're up slightly year-over-year a little over 76% share. And FIRST RESPONSE again, is the #1 brand in pregnancy test kits. And we're the first people to come out to try a Bluetooth-enabled pregnancy test kit. So that's our -- what we're trying to do there is test and learn in what we call the Internet of Things. So we have a very robust new product development process. We're very focused on consumer insights and that does lead us to really cool ideas with respect to new products. And we've got a nice pipeline for 2017 and 2018. So that gives us confidence that we continue to grow the top line organically.

componenttext: Also, Caroline, I think we are right on our expectations for buyback. We said we were going to do around [ph] $300 million of share buybacks and we got $100 million in December. We did about $200 million in February, and if you look at our past practice, we typically get ahead of our full year buyback in Q1. So $300 million is right on target. We feel good about that and that number, I think as you've seen us in the past, if we go many, many, many years without doing an acquisition and we have the cash buildup on the balance sheet and we always go back and say how do we return that to shareholders.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Joe Altobello.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question on the categories. Obviously, getting better. You did mention back in February that could be potential upside to guidance. Is there any larger sort of take away on the broader consumer in the U.S. from the fact that 11 of your 15 categories
componenttext: First question on the categories. Obviously, getting better. You did mention back in February that could be potential upside to guidance. Is there any larger sort of take away on the broader consumer in the U.S. from the fact that 11 of your 15 categories were up.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, Joe. So everybody has their own crystal ball about the economy, and we do look at that the same way. So we always moderate those 15 categories. So 11 of the 15 up, it's a very good sign. And before, they weren't up are some of
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Joe. So everybody has their own crystal ball about the economy, and we do look at that the same way. So we always moderate those 15 categories. So 11 of the 15 up, it's a very good sign. And before, they weren't up are some of the -- at least 3 of them were some of the smaller categories. So I would say, yes, that is a good sign. But as you have to temper that by looking at some of the big houses with the big banks who recently have reduced the GDP outlook for the U.S., this year to 1.5% because obviously, there is some pessimism out there. The credit card debt is going up. Some people speculate the fuel savings are going through healthcare costs. So this definitely, a couple of different camps out there with respect to the economy. From our part, we do look at these categories and we see a lot of strength in them. So we don't think that's going to turnaround that quickly. We should say strong for the rest of the year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how are retailers managing inventories? Are they getting more or actually less conservative given that?
componenttext: And how are retailers managing inventories? Are they getting more or actually less conservative given that?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that. I think the retailers are no different than any of the CPG companies, and everybody looks at working capital very closely. So no, I wouldn't say there would be any change in practice there.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. I think the retailers are no different than any of the CPG companies, and everybody looks at working capital very closely. So no, I wouldn't say there would be any change in practice there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that the kids gummies, the category was down 8%. Just curious what drove that.
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that the kids gummies, the category was down 8%. Just curious what drove that.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the kids gummies section has been trending down for more than just this quarter, for a while. And the speculation around that is that once upon a time, before the advent of adult gummies, the adults took kids gummies. And with a lot of adult gummies
componenttext: Yes, the kids gummies section has been trending down for more than just this quarter, for a while. And the speculation around that is that once upon a time, before the advent of adult gummies, the adults took kids gummies. And with a lot of adult gummies now coming on shelf, adults are using the adult gummies and not the kids. So that's why I said earlier is that our focus is on adults. Kids is a very mature category even when we bought the business, if you look at vitamins, 2/3 of all the vitamins that children in the U.S. were gummies. So we saw already saturated. So this is the migration from kids to adults.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one last one, I have to ask on OxiClean, laundry detergent in fact, the shares were down again a little bit this quarter. What's you're thinking there? Maybe plans for that brand going forward in that category.
componenttext: Got it. And one last one, I have to ask on OxiClean, laundry detergent in fact, the shares were down again a little bit this quarter. What's you're thinking there? Maybe plans for that brand going forward in that category.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, it's no secret that you have a new entrant into high-end laundry detergent last year with Persil brand and they went to Walmart and Amazon, and at the end of the year and now, they're expanding and doing a lot of couponing, et cetera. So there'
componenttext: Yes, well, it's no secret that you have a new entrant into high-end laundry detergent last year with Persil brand and they went to Walmart and Amazon, and at the end of the year and now, they're expanding and doing a lot of couponing, et cetera. So there's -- the activity is very fierce right now with respect to couponing from those guys. So obviously, we would be a victim of some of that, so we lost some share. But as I said in my earlier remarks, you're right. In the quarter, we did lose 20 basis points of share. I feel like the more recent week, we're back to a 1 share. But the service stay at 1 share right now. We're really trying to crack the code here, and figure out how to grow that brand. But we're still committed to it.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, when we talk about the international position, we have our countries or we have 6 primary countries and we have an export business. We have found that we have a lot of success with our products and a lot of countries, all in those 6 countries
componenttext: Well, look, when we talk about the international position, we have our countries or we have 6 primary countries and we have an export business. We have found that we have a lot of success with our products and a lot of countries, all in those 6 countries that I mentioned where we have subsidiaries. And we've got a terrific leadership team in the export business and they've been driving a lot of growth. And when you have people that are successful like that, and they have plans to execute, to drive that growth, we say we're going to add the headcount. And you know how stingy we are around here about the -- hedged, we're going to invest behind these guys in export. And we're also doing the same in the Specialty Products Division. We bought a business a year ago, a small business to add to our animal productivity business. And likewise, we have the ability to go international with some of those products as well. This is both in dairy and in poultry. So we're going to invest in the future. And because we had a rocking first quarter and things are looking up for the year, we said hey, it's a good time to reinvest.

componenttext: A follow-up on domestic growth trending above channels. I know it's a small base. But how much of that was from strengthened e-commerce? And what, if anything, are you guys doing differently about areas online demand accelerates?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. Most CPG companies have their online sales between 1% and 3%. And when I say 1% -- that range would include all the usual suspects. The Amazon.com, Walmart.com, target.com, et cetera, et cetera. So I would say mostly CPG companies are
componenttext: Yes, good question. Most CPG companies have their online sales between 1% and 3%. And when I say 1% -- that range would include all the usual suspects. The Amazon.com, Walmart.com, target.com, et cetera, et cetera. So I would say mostly CPG companies are in the early innings with respect to selling products online, of course, very quickly. For our part I want to say change very quickly. It's not going to go to 5% or 10% in just a couple of years, but it will change over time. So we've decided that we want to get really good at that. So it's one of our focuses right now. It did not -- was not a big contributor, I would say, to the first quarter results. But we are going to have higher online sales this year-over-year by a meaningful percentage year-over-year.

componenttextpreview: Congrats to the strong start to the year. I wanted to come back nd sort's of rehash some of the questions that have already been asked. First, to bill Chevelle's question on the gross margin. 300 basis points he gets to automatically seems pretty optimist
componenttext: Congrats to the strong start to the year. I wanted to come back nd sort's of rehash some of the questions that have already been asked. First, to bill Chevelle's question on the gross margin. 300 basis points he gets to automatically seems pretty optimistic. But I agree with his general premise that mathematically, it's not that hard to get well above where you're guiding to. So a couple of questions just to help us sort of understand this. First, commodities. Is there something to consider in terms of your hedge positions for last year, this year, et cetera that may cause your benefit or lack thereof to be greater or worse than what you're seeing in spot markets. And then secondly, the leakage on the fixed costs resource for the new vitamin plant I appreciate that that's here to stay for a while but are suing going to lap the start-up expenses to those to effectively wash? Or our expectation was that we would actually get a surplus that the start-up costs were greater than sort of the fixed cost deleveraging that you're getting there?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So fix commodity first. So we had said previously, and it's still of the case of in general, resin was down 10% was down 20%. Paper was relatively flat oil and diesel are doing and those are favorable year-over-year as well. I think in general,
componenttext: Yes, sure. So fix commodity first. So we had said previously, and it's still of the case of in general, resin was down 10% was down 20%. Paper was relatively flat oil and diesel are doing and those are favorable year-over-year as well. I think in general, we do have some hedges out there. We entered the year was about 30% hedged, which is really our lowest level of quite a few years because we thought we should float most of the market. We do have a couple of hedges on surfactants. But so may be we're not getting the entire spot market benefit. But in general, 200 basis points is not realistic for us at all. So we do have that as a tailwind. In general, from commodities, fixed cost for vitamins now remember we told you guys this was a 75% increase in capacity. So a $300 million business becomes $525 million. it's going to take some time to really grow into those fixed overheads. And you're right, we had start-up costs last year. But those fixed overheads are more in totality than the start-up costs were a year ago.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. And then back to laundry category growth. We see the lower promotional activity. We see some of the mix up that's happening in the category. But when we do our best to start to get to get the low equivalent volume we're seeing on a load of Herbalife basis growing North of 3%, which is a bit of a head scratcher right not because it's hard to imagine people just decided to have more dirty clothes are doing more laundry. Any views on what's driving that volumetric growth from a low to globalize perspective?

componenttext: I think I have to agree with you, Jason. That's a head scratcher. Because I -- in the past at times we think sometimes the information we was on volume we have to take with a grain of salt because the oil is different sizes within the category. Okay. If you would think about the wash loads. So it's a lot more wash loads. It's illogical, I think there's 3% or 4% more wash loads being done with population growth only 1.5%. Hey, Jason, the other thing there, is we do see trends. There's a certain percentage of the category that does mix odds and liquid laundry. So that might throw off your wash load Mr.X as well.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regardin
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Before we begin, I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding, among other things, the company's financial objectives and forecasts. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and other factors that are described in detail in the company's SEC filings. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Matt Farrell, Chief Executive Officer of Church & Dwight. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. It's always a pleasure to talk to you about our business. I'll start with a brief review of our first quarter results, which you read about in this morning's press release. I'll then direct the rest of my comments towards our categ
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. It's always a pleasure to talk to you about our business. I'll start with a brief review of our first quarter results, which you read about in this morning's press release. I'll then direct the rest of my comments towards our categories. 
I'm going to turn the call over to Rick Dierker when I'm done. Rick will comment on each business. That's Domestic, International and Specialty Products and also review the outlook for Q2 and for the full year. When Rick is finished, I'll get back on and we'll open the call up to questions. 
So here are the highlights. In short, Q1 was a terrific quarter for Church & Dwight. We delivered organic sales growth of 5.2% and 7.5% EPS growth, which is 10% EPS growth on a currency-neutral basis. Category growth was broad-based in that 11 of our 15 categories grew in the quarter. From a market share perspective, 6 of our 10 power brands grew share. So all-in, these results are top-tier in consumer products. Now I'd like to provide you with some color on a few of our categories. That would be laundry, litter, vitamins and dry shampoo. 
The laundry category is strong, growing 6.4% versus year-ago. This is the fourth quarter in a row of laundry category growth. The value segment grew 6.1%, and this is the sixth consecutive quarter of value segment growth. In fact, for the last 4 quarters, value has grown on average 4.5% per quarter. The laundry category growth was driven by growth in both the unit dose and liquid segments. The value liquid segment grew at an 8% clip, driven by ARM & HAMMER liquid, which grew consumption a whopping 11% year-over-year. 
With respect to unit dose, this form now represents 15% of the laundry category. Our unit dose consumption grew 15% in the quarter. More recently, we have launched new 2-chamber unit dose products under the OxiClean and ARM & HAMMER brands. We expect these new products to contribute to future consumption growth. Most of the resets for these launches happened in late March and early April. 
Now I'd like to take a few minutes to talk about our 3 laundry brands. ARM & HAMMER has been our big franchise in laundry for many years. And the ARM & HAMMER laundry share continued to grow this quarter, up 30 basis points. To illustrate the strength of the ARM & HAMMER brand, ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry has grown share year-over-year in 25 consecutive quarters. 
Our XTRA brand backed off promotional volume in Q1, which improved our year-over-year profitability but resulted in our giving up 40 basis points of share. On a full-year basis, we expect XTRA net sales and profits to be up year-over-year. 
Oxi laundry share was down 10 basis points year-over-year. As we, like others, felt the effect of Persil's promotional activity. In the most recent 4-week period, we are back to a 1 share. So promotional phasing does influence shares. If we look at how OxiClean is doing in the stain fighter additive category, OxiClean's share hit an all-time high of 48% share. 
Now I'm going to turn my comments to cat litter. The clumping litter segment continued to show strong growth at 5.3%. ARM & HAMMER litter was one of the winners in the quarter. We continue to grow faster than the segment. Our consumption grew 6.7% behind our latest innovation, MicroGuard CLUMP & SEAL litter. 
Just a quick commercial. MicroGuard seals and destroys odors, and prevents future bacterial odors from forming. It's an innovative product and we are broadcasting that message on our package that 98% of consumers, who have tried the product, would recommend it. 
Now let's talk about vitamins. The overall VMS category continues to show steady growth, up 3%. The gummy segment of VMS grew almost 15% in Q1. And so let me break down the 15% for you. The adult gummy segment grew 23% while the kids gummy segment declined 8%. Adult gummies is where we are putting our focus as it is underdeveloped and it will be the source of future growth for us. Our brand, Vitafusion, is the largest brand in the adult gummy category and was the biggest driver of the 23% adult segment category growth. The good news this quarter is that our gummy business is growing again. 
We have had wide retailer acceptance of our new adult beauty line, which hit shores -- which hit store shelves in March. So we are off to a good start this year for vitamins. The last category I want to address is dry shampoo. This category grew 26% in Q1 year-over-year. A, the category in the U.S. is nearly $100 million with the potential to be a $300 million category in the U.S. if we match the historical category growth experienced in the U.K. 
Batiste is the #1 brand in the U.S. with a 17.2% share. Batiste global net sales will cross $100 million this year, making it the #1 dry shampoo brand globally. So it's no surprise that the Batiste brand is expected to be one of our fastest growing brands in the future. 
Many new products are shipping right now. I've mentioned dual chamber pods, MicroGuard litter and the vitamin beauty line. In addition, we have the new GROOVE condom and RIVIERA lubricant by TROJAN; and the new Bluetooth-enabled pregnancy test kit from First Response. 
We feel good about our distribution, and we look forward to these products contributing to our organic growth in 2016. Our goal is to continue to focus on consumer insights, leading us to innovative new products to drive share and category growth. 
Next up is Rick to give you details on our first quarter results and the outlook for Q2 and the full year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. First quarter reported EPS was $0.86 per share compared to $0.80 in 2015, up 7.5%. The $0.86 was better than our $0.83 outlook, largely due to organic revenue beat and gross margin expansi
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. First quarter reported EPS was $0.86 per share compared to $0.80 in 2015, up 7.5%. The $0.86 was better than our $0.83 outlook, largely due to organic revenue beat and gross margin expansion beat. Netted in that $0.86 is $0.02 or 2.5% drag from currency year-over-year. 
Reported revenues were up 4.5% to $849 million. Organic sales were 5.2%, exceeding our Q1 outlook of approximately 2% to 3%. The organic sales beat was driven by our consumer business, both domestic and international. 
Now let's review the segments. The Consumer Domestic business' organic sales increased by 4.5%, driven by the continued success of our ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry detergent, Vitafusion gummy vitamin, Batiste dry shampoo and ARM & HAMMER CLUMP & SEAL cat litter. We now expect the full year organic sales to be approximately 3% for the Consumer Domestic business. 
International organic growth was up an impressive 13.3%. Now some of that was timing as orders are a little lumpy in the export business, but underlying growth was very strong at approximately 9%. Here again, we are raising our expectation for the full year. Organic growth from 4% to approximately 5% to 6% for the consumer international business. 
For our Specialty Products Division, organic sales was down 2%, driven by further declines in milk pricing and a difficult comp of 11% growth year-ago. Milk prices have come down 10% in the last 90 days as there is an oversupply globally. And as a result, U.S. exports, which historically have been 15% plus of U.S. production, are now around 10%. We have lowered our expectations for the full year for the SPD division from up 1% to 3% to down 2%. This is a headwind that we expect to overcome for the full year and we still like this business, but we do experience these cycles from time to time. 
Turning now to gross margin. Our reported first quarter gross margin was 44.6%, an 80 basis point increase from year-ago. Q1 gross margin benefited from 3 factors: lower commodities, productivity programs and the higher-margin from acquired businesses. These factors were partially offset by foreign exchange, negative product mix and higher fixed costs associated with our new vitamin capacity in our York facility. 
Moving to marketing. We increased marketing spend by 4.2% year-over-year. Marketing as a percent of revenue was consistent with 2015 at 10.9%. SG&A as a percentage of net sales was 12.6%, a 90 basis point increase from the prior year. This was primarily due to incremental amortization from acquisitions and the timing of management stock compensation. 
Now to operating profit. The reported operating margin for the quarter was 21.1%, which was 10 basis points lower than the prior year. Other income and expense was $6.4 million, largely $7 million of expense related to interest expense. Next is income taxes. Our effective rate for the quarter is 34.7%. 
And turning to cash. We had a strong cash flow quarter. We generated $178 million of net cash for the first quarter, a $33 million increase from the same quarter year-ago. So in conclusion, the first quarter highlights include 5.2% organic, 7.5% EPS growth, which again equates to a 10% currency-neutral EPS growth. 
Turning to the second quarter outlook. We expect Q2 organic sales growth of approximately 2% to 3%, and I know a lot of you guys like to look at growth on a 2-year stack basis. Remember, for the total company, year ago, Q2 was 5% organic. So on a 2-year stack, Q1 and Q2 look pretty similar at approximately 8%. 
And if we just focus in on the Consumer Domestic business for a minute. The 2-year stack is going from 6.1% in Q1 to almost 8% in Q2. So a lot of positive momentum continuing on. 
We expect marketing as a percentage of revenue to be flat year-over-year and gross margin to expand in Q2. We expect second quarter earnings per share of approximately $0.79 compared to an adjusted $0.73 per share year-ago or an 8% increase year-over-year. 
And now turning to the full year. To summarize our thinking, we are raising our expectations for organic sales growth from 3% to 3% to 4%. In February, we called approximately 40 basis points of gross margin expansion, and we're pleased to say that now, we're calling 70 basis points of gross margin expansion -- 75. 
Back in February, this broke out as 70 basis points of help from commodities and productivity, offset by 30 basis points from currency headwinds. The 75 basis points we expect now is 100 basis points from commodities and productivity programs, offset by a 25 basis point drag from currency. We're more optimistic about the stability of commodity pricing across the entire commodity basket for the full year than we were a quarter ago. Our full-year marketing expectation continues to be 12.3% of sales, consistent with 2015 and prior years. 
Moving to SG&A. Our original expectations were a 10 basis point reduction. We now expect a 25 basis point increase largely behind R&D, IT and Internet international sales force investments. 
Let me give you a little color on these investments. First, investing in R&D projects behind our future product portfolio. Second, investing in our international sales force, footprint, specifically in high-growth areas of our business to drive future growth. And third, we expect higher ongoing IT infrastructure costs as we implement 2 new important systems: our spec management system for R&D and our trade management system for sales. We are positioning ourselves well for the future. We continue to expect the 2 basis points of operating margin expansion. 
Next is income tax. We now expect 34.7% for the full year. So it's a little higher than our previous outlook of 34.5%. We continue to expect $630 million of free cash flow net of approximately $55 million of CapEx for full year 2016. This represents 125% free cash flow conversion. 
So now Matt and I will open it up for questions.

componenttext: Look, I don't have the crystal ball to say if we're going to have mid-single digit the whole year. That's going to be a function of year-over-year comps, right? But all I can say is if we look at the trends, the trends have been strong with respect to liquid laundry for the last 6 quarters and certainly the last 4, and no reason to expect that won't continue in the future.

componenttext: Yes, I want to clarify what -- the only headcount aspect of the incremental SG&A investment is really around -- hasn't been done yet. We expect those to happen throughout the year.

componenttext: Yes, one of the reasons I chose to speak about the categories upfront, Kevin, is because laundry, litter, vitamins and more recently, the dry shampoo categories are catalysts to the company. componenttext: Can you talk about the gross margin progression? Because like the natural flow of the business, and if you look at what some of other folks in laundry have done, just given like the year-over-year decline, a lot of commodity cost, the gross margin should naturally be a lot higher. And obviously, you beat your guidance and raised it for the full year, but what is kind of offsetting that natural flow-through of what you would expect given this commodity and category growth environment?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill, I think that's a fair question. We talked about it a little bit on our Analyst Day, and we kind of talked through some of the headwinds like transactional currency, but I'd say overall, we're really pleased with our gross margin expansion. We j
componenttext: Yes, Bill, I think that's a fair question. We talked about it a little bit on our Analyst Day, and we kind of talked through some of the headwinds like transactional currency, but I'd say overall, we're really pleased with our gross margin expansion. We just talked about how we're going from 40 basis points to 75. So essentially, we're doubling it. And that entire doubling of it is largely commodity. So I think we feel more comfortable with that full year outlook of commodities. So do we have one-offs every now and then on write-offs and whatnot to hand that burden, gross margin? Sure. But overall, in general, we're really happy about doubling our gross margin outlook pretty much. And if commodities continue to stay where they're at or improve, we'll probably be talking about it again.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then I know this is a small one and maybe somewhat nitpicky, but on the Spencer Forrest acquisition, I think you spent $175 million for $30 million of sales. Like is there a massive growth trajectory of the business? Is that why you paid such a high multiple of sales?

componenttext: Yes, I think we probably got similar questions like that when we bought Batiste back in 2011. The way to think about that, Bill, is that hair thinning category is about a $240 million category. That's mostly dominated by topicals, senior brands like ROGAINE. And our point of view is that hair thinning can also be addressed with hair fibers, and we bought a product that we think is going to have significant growth in future because it addresses the problem in a cosmetic fashion and not with chemicals.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about your new products. You went through some stuff pretty quickly. But can you elaborate on some of the major ideas and why you think that this is going to keep the momentum strong and if you think your market share gains can continue?
componenttext: I wanted to talk about your new products. You went through some stuff pretty quickly. But can you elaborate on some of the major ideas and why you think that this is going to keep the momentum strong and if you think your market share gains can continue?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been the leader in the litter category for many years now. If you remember when we spoke downtown in February and we showed a chart that showed our innovations over the past 3 or 4 years. So we've clearly been the catalyst for that category, a
componenttext: Well, we've been the leader in the litter category for many years now. If you remember when we spoke downtown in February and we showed a chart that showed our innovations over the past 3 or 4 years. So we've clearly been the catalyst for that category, and we have a winner again this year with the MicroGuard product. So we're driving growth in the category, which is a big category, and we're taking share. And we generally have a big new idea every year, so we think we can continue that in the future. With respect to laundry, as I said earlier, well, ARM & HAMMER has been quite a powerhouse for us for a long time. The new product this year is -- one of them, is the BioEnzyme product, which has the EPA/Safer Choice label, which is becoming more meaningful to all shoppers. So we think that's a nice new variant for us that's going to help us continue to grow the franchise. Some of these other things that I mentioned, vitamins, what we did was we decided to shrinkwrap our products. So we got beautiful new packaging, which obviously speaks out or pops on shelf, and we think that, that is going to be a winner for us this year as well. Continuing down the line, in the TROJAN, TROJAN RIVIERA, so this is -- you may recall this is a lubricant that can be used in the shower. So that's another consumer insight that we think is going to help expand the share for TROJAN. And as you know, TROJAN's share continues to grow. We're up slightly year over year, a little over 76% share. And First Response, again, is the #1 brand in pregnancy test kits. And we're the first people to come out to try a Bluetooth-enabled pregnancy test kit. So that's our -- what we're trying to do there is test and learn in, what we call, the Internet of Things. So we have a very robust new product development process. We're very focused on consumer insights, and that does lead us to really cool ideas with respect to new products, and we've got a nice pipeline for 2017 and 2018. So that gives us confidence that we continue to grow the top line organically.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Caroline, I think we are right on our expectations for buyback. We said we're going to do around $300 million this year of buybacks and we got -- we did $100 million in December, we did about $200 million in February. And if you look at our past practi
componenttext: So Caroline, I think we are right on our expectations for buyback. We said we're going to do around $300 million this year of buybacks and we got -- we did $100 million in December, we did about $200 million in February. And if you look at our past practice, we typically get ahead of our full year buyback in Q1. So $300 million is right on target. We feel good about that number. I think, as you have seen us in the past, if we go many, many, many years without doing an acquisition and we have the cash build up on the balance sheet, then we always look back and say, "How do we return that to shareholders?"

componenttextpreview: So you could step it up in the fourth quarter, but don't expect much for the balance of the year, probably?
componenttext: So you could step it up in the fourth quarter, but don't expect much for the balance of the year, probably?

componenttext: Yes, I would say that $300 million is our sweet spot for this year, as of now.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Joe Altobello.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Joe Altobello.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question on the categories, obviously getting better. You did mention back in February that could be potential upside to guidance. Is there any larger sort of takeaway on the broader consumer in the U.S. from the fact that 11 of your 15 categories w
componenttext: First question on the categories, obviously getting better. You did mention back in February that could be potential upside to guidance. Is there any larger sort of takeaway on the broader consumer in the U.S. from the fact that 11 of your 15 categories were up?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, Joe. So everybody has their own crystal ball about the economy and we do look at it the same way. So we always monitor those 15 categories. So having 11 of the 15 up is a very good sign, and the 4 that weren't up are some of t
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Joe. So everybody has their own crystal ball about the economy and we do look at it the same way. So we always monitor those 15 categories. So having 11 of the 15 up is a very good sign, and the 4 that weren't up are some of the -- at least 3 of them are some of the smaller categories. So I would say yes, that is a good sign. But, of course, you have to temper that by if you look at some of the big houses, most of the big banks more recently have reduced their GDP outlook for the U.S. this year to 1.5%. So obviously there is some pessimism out there. The credit card debt is going up. Some people speculate that fuel savings are going to health care costs. So there is definitely a couple different camps out there with respect to the economy. From -- for our part, we do look at these categories and we see a lot of strength in them. So we don't think that's going to turn around that quickly. We think it should stay strong for the rest of the year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how are retailers managing inventories? Are they getting a little bit more or actually less conservative given that?
componenttext: And how are retailers managing inventories? Are they getting a little bit more or actually less conservative given that?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that. I think the retailers are no different than any of the CPG companies, and everybody looks at working capital very closely. So no, I wouldn't say there'd be any change in practice there.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. I think the retailers are no different than any of the CPG companies, and everybody looks at working capital very closely. So no, I wouldn't say there'd be any change in practice there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that kids gummies, the category was down 8%. Just curious what drove that.
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that kids gummies, the category was down 8%. Just curious what drove that.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the kids gummy section has been trending down for more than just this quarter, for a while. And the speculation around that is that once upon a time, before the advent of adult gummies, the adults took kids gummies. And that with a lot of adult gummi
componenttext: Yes, the kids gummy section has been trending down for more than just this quarter, for a while. And the speculation around that is that once upon a time, before the advent of adult gummies, the adults took kids gummies. And that with a lot of adult gummies now coming on shelf, adults are using the adult gummies and not the kids. So that's why I said earlier is that our focus is on adults. Kids is a very mature category. Even when we bought the business, if you looked at vitamins, 2/3 of all the vitamins that children took in the U.S. were gummies. So it was just already saturated and so there is some migration from kids to adults.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And one last one, I have to ask. On OxiClean laundry detergent, it looks like the shares were down again a little bit this quarter. What's your thinking there? Maybe plans for that brand going forward in that category.
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And one last one, I have to ask. On OxiClean laundry detergent, it looks like the shares were down again a little bit this quarter. What's your thinking there? Maybe plans for that brand going forward in that category.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- well, look, it's no secret that you have a new entrant into high-end laundry detergent last year with Henkel's Persil brand, and they went to Walmart and Amazon. And then at the end of the year and now, they're expanding and doing a lot of co
componenttext: Yes, it's -- well, look, it's no secret that you have a new entrant into high-end laundry detergent last year with Henkel's Persil brand, and they went to Walmart and Amazon. And then at the end of the year and now, they're expanding and doing a lot of couponing, et cetera. So there is -- the activity is very fierce right now with respect to couponing from those guys. So obviously, we would be a victim of some of that. So we lost some share, but as I said in my earlier remarks, we -- you're right. In the quarter, we did lose 20 basis points of share. If you look to more recent week, we're back to a one share, but it's sort of a steady state, one share right now. We're really trying to crack the code here and figure out how to grow that brand, but we're still committed to it.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gere.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I guess, obviously every few years one of your big competitors finds some cost-cutting initiatives in place and everybody kind of fears about what could happen to some of the categories. And laundry, in particular, the category seems t
componenttext: Two questions. One, I guess, obviously every few years one of your big competitors finds some cost-cutting initiatives in place and everybody kind of fears about what could happen to some of the categories. And laundry, in particular, the category seems to be strong. So you talked a little bit about Persil and a little bit of the couponing there. Is there anything on the front from that big competitor right now that they may go after some of the shares that they've seen either at the high end or even push more behind their value brand just to get greater growth?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Jason. I don't have any intelligence other than what you see in the marketplace today that there are big pushes in the high end with Persil, pretty aggressive claims. And there is nothing more to report from that competitor.
componenttext: No, Jason. I don't have any intelligence other than what you see in the marketplace today that there are big pushes in the high end with Persil, pretty aggressive claims. And there is nothing more to report from that competitor.

componenttext: Okay. Well, how about the other competitor? The bigger one? The big dog. headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's good. And then the other question, just going back to some of the investments on the international sales force. I know you talked a lot more about the export business. But just kind of curious. Your thoughts -- you've been predominantly a
componenttext: Okay. No, that's good. And then the other question, just going back to some of the investments on the international sales force. I know you talked a lot more about the export business. But just kind of curious. Your thoughts -- you've been predominantly a domestic business, with some of the categories being able to carry over to your, I guess, your -- more your North American international counterparts, Mexico, Canada, et cetera. But with this expansion in international, does it change your thinking about the portfolio you have, getting greater expansion whether in new markets or even with expanding some of the categories that you're in domestically? So just wondering if we should read into anything there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, the -- when we talk about the international division, we have our countries. So we have 6 primary countries, and then we have an export business. Now we have found that we've had a lot of success with our products in a lot of countries other t
componenttext: Well, look, the -- when we talk about the international division, we have our countries. So we have 6 primary countries, and then we have an export business. Now we have found that we've had a lot of success with our products in a lot of countries other than those 6 countries that I mentioned where we have subsidiaries. And we've got a terrific leadership team in the export business and they've been driving a lot of growth. And when you have people that are successful like that and they have plans to execute to drive that growth, we've said we're going to add the head count. And you know how stingy we are around here about adding heads. So we're going to invest behind these guys in export, and we're also doing the same in the Specialty Products Division. We bought a business a year ago, a small business, to add to our animal productivity business. And likewise, we have the ability to go international with some of those products as well. This is both in the dairy and the poultry. So we're going to invest for the future, and because we had a rocking first quarter and things are looking up for the year, we said, "Hey, this is a good time to reinvest."

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up on domestic growth trending above channels. I know it's a small base, but how much of that was from strength in e-commerce? And what, if anything, are you guys doing differently in that area as online demand accelerates?
componenttext: A follow-up on domestic growth trending above channels. I know it's a small base, but how much of that was from strength in e-commerce? And what, if anything, are you guys doing differently in that area as online demand accelerates?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. Most CPG companies have their online sales between 1% and 3%. And when I say 1% -- that range would include all the usual suspects: the Amazon.com, Walmart.com, Target.com, et cetera, et cetera. So I would say most CPG compani
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. Most CPG companies have their online sales between 1% and 3%. And when I say 1% -- that range would include all the usual suspects: the Amazon.com, Walmart.com, Target.com, et cetera, et cetera. So I would say most CPG companies are in the early innings with respect to selling products online. Now, of course, that can change very quickly. For our part, when I say change very quickly, I mean, it's not going to go to 5% or 10% in just a couple years, but it will change over time. So we've decided that we want to get really good at that. So it's one of our focuses right now. It did not -- was not a big contributor, I would say, to the first quarter results. But we are going to have higher online sales this year, year-over-year -- by a meaningful percentage year-over-year.

componenttext: Yes, and let me put a little bit of context behind it, too. We're talking about a move of going from down 10 basis points in SG&A to up 25. headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to come back and sort of rehash some of the questions that have already been asked. First, to Bill Schmitz's question on gross margins. 300 basis points that he gets to mathematically seems pretty optimistic, but I agree with his general premise
componenttext: I wanted to come back and sort of rehash some of the questions that have already been asked. First, to Bill Schmitz's question on gross margins. 300 basis points that he gets to mathematically seems pretty optimistic, but I agree with his general premise that mathematically it's not that hard to get well above where you're guiding to. So a couple of questions, just to help us sort of understand this. First, commodities, is there something to consider in terms of your hedge positions for last year, this year, et cetera, that may cause your benefit or lack thereof to be greater or worse than what we'd see in sort of spot markets? And then, secondly, the leakage on the fixed-cost absorption for the new vitamin plant, I appreciate that's -- it's here to stay for a while, but you're soon going to start to lap the startup expenses. Do those 2 effectively wash, or our expectation was that you could actually get a surplus, that the startup costs were greater than sort of the fixed-cost deleverage you're getting now?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So I'll take the commodity question first. So we had said previously, and it's still the case that, in general, resin was down 10%, surfactants were down 20%, paper was relatively flat. You guys know what oil and diesel are doing, and those are
componenttext: Yes, sure. So I'll take the commodity question first. So we had said previously, and it's still the case that, in general, resin was down 10%, surfactants were down 20%, paper was relatively flat. You guys know what oil and diesel are doing, and those are favorable year-over-year as well. I think in general, we do have some hedges out there. We went into the year with about 30% hedge, which is really our lowest level in quite a few years because we thought we should float most of the market. We do have a couple hedges on surfactants, but -- so maybe we're not getting the entire spot market benefit. But in general 300 basis points is not realistic for us at all. So we do have that as a tailwind, in general, from commodities. Fixed costs for vitamins, now remember we told you guys this was a 75% increase in capacity. So a $300 million business becomes $525 million. It's going to take some time to really grow into those fixed overheads. And you're right, we had startup costs last year, but those fixed overheads are more in totality than the startup costs were a year ago.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. That's helpful. And then back to laundry category growth. We see the lower promotional activity. We see some of the mix-up that's happening in the category, but when we do our best to try to get to a load equivalent volume, we're seeing vo
componenttext: That's helpful. That's helpful. And then back to laundry category growth. We see the lower promotional activity. We see some of the mix-up that's happening in the category, but when we do our best to try to get to a load equivalent volume, we're seeing volume on a load equivalized basis growing north of 3%, which is a bit of a head scratcher, right, because it's hard to imagine that people have just decided -- or have more dirty clothes or doing more laundry. Any views on what's driving that volumetric growth from a load equivalized perspective?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I have to agree with you, Jason. That is a head scratcher. I could say in the past at times, we think sometimes that the information that we use on volume, you have to take with a grain of salt because they all have different sizes within the
componenttext: Yes, I think I have to agree with you, Jason. That is a head scratcher. I could say in the past at times, we think sometimes that the information that we use on volume, you have to take with a grain of salt because they all have different sizes within the category. If you think about wash loads, so if you're saying there's a lot more wash loads, it's illogical to think that there's 3% or 4% more wash loads being done with population growth only 1.5%.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, the other thing there is we do see trends. There's a certain percentage of the category that does mix pods and liquid laundry. So that might throw off your wash load metrics as well.
componenttext: Jason, the other thing there is we do see trends. There's a certain percentage of the category that does mix pods and liquid laundry. So that might throw off your wash load metrics as well.

componenttext: Just 2 quick ones from me. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your, I guess, latest power brand, Batiste, and provide some context around the opportunity in the U.S. I think dry shampoo is a bigger part of the shampoo category in the U.K. But could you give us maybe some metrics there so we can try and understand the opportunity that lies ahead here in the U.S.? componenttext: Yes, as far as the context for Batiste opportunity is if you look at the U.K., the U.K., round numbers, has about 60 million people, and it has -- the category there is about $60 million. And so just do the quick math, you have 335 million people in the U.S. You have 5x the population, so you've got an opportunity for 5x the category size. So the $60 million becomes $300 million here. So that really is the math behind the thinking that this could be a much bigger category.
