And so with the full year at a 7% to 8%, and that means second half is going to be closer to 4%, 5% that's really the context you should think of international growth for the year.

I just wonder if you could weigh in a little bit how much of the strength you've seen in this year is aided by even more distribution wins. And I'm guessing it's pretty broad based where you're seeing it but just if you can comment on which businesses you're having those wins have in the most impact. I'm assuming things like vitamins and Batiste, but again, some context there would be helpful.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, there's no question you hit the 2 that are leading the pack 1 is vitamins where us as he said in my opening remarks that we have a 5% increase in distribution, which is pretty significant because obviously, that carries over into future quarters.
componenttext: Yes, no, there's no question you hit the 2 that are leading the pack 1 is vitamins where us as he said in my opening remarks that we have a 5% increase in distribution, which is pretty significant because obviously, that carries over into future quarters. And then Batiste is just a craze. So it's getting more and more shelf space. And when there are more and more shelf space retailers becoming more interested in it so it seems like almost every quarter now, we're gaining more distribution and that has compounding effect that's why we -- although it's a small brand, we continue to talk about it because it is influencing our numbers. So you've hit on the 2 big ones there.

componenttext: Got it. Okay, okay. So some carryover into next year. And then back to the questions on the volume trajectory, which there's been a few, right? But you are suggesting that volume decelerates on both the sort of stand-alone and 2-year stack basis, particularly on 2-year stack pretty substantially despite the incremental spend. So implicitly, you seem to be suggesting that you're not expecting a lot of volumetric response to the incremental promotional dollars you're putting into market. Is that a fair interpretation? And if so, why?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. I think I went into the detail of why it's not just the incremental promotional spending up against some higher comps for vitamins and the category counts for laundry, for example, and the whole international, strong growth, th
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things. I think I went into the detail of why it's not just the incremental promotional spending up against some higher comps for vitamins and the category counts for laundry, for example, and the whole international, strong growth, the deceleration. We're spending quite a bit of money back on marketing, right? And that's going to take some time to really pull through demand. On incremental trade and really couponing spending, those investments are really to drive trial from new products. That's the crux of it. And so we wanted to get that repeat rate up. It's too early to call volume upside from driving trial. So really, we're just really in the process, Jason. And we think that when we get back up to our competitor's levels of promotion just on par with what we had a year ago even, we think that will be a nice momentum as we exit 2016.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to add to that, Jason. If we went to the first quarter 2015, the laundry category declined round numbers, 1.5%. And then first quarter '16, it was up 6.5%. So on a stack basis, a lot of people like to talk on a stack basis, you'd say laundry was
componenttext: Yes. Just to add to that, Jason. If we went to the first quarter 2015, the laundry category declined round numbers, 1.5%. And then first quarter '16, it was up 6.5%. So on a stack basis, a lot of people like to talk on a stack basis, you'd say laundry was up 5% on a 2-year basis. And Q2 on a 2-year basis stack, it was 4%. If you go to 3 and 4 last year, Q3 was 2.5% and Q4 was 3.5%. So that would suggest you're going to see deceleration in laundry. If you're a believer in the stack theory, and if we think it's going to be around from 4% to 5%, we're seeing a deceleration in the laundry category on a year-over-year basis. So who knows? That's just math. But it's something to think about.

And then how do we think about it as a driver from an international standpoint? Is it fair to call it the majority of international growth? Or is it just not big enough?

componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to what our sales are by country, we wouldn't get into that. And one thing I would like to dispel is the belief that the Batiste is the sole driver of the international business. ARM & HAMMER is growing quite a bit in Canada and Mexico.
componenttext: Well, with respect to what our sales are by country, we wouldn't get into that. And one thing I would like to dispel is the belief that the Batiste is the sole driver of the international business. ARM & HAMMER is growing quite a bit in Canada and Mexico. And this is kind of anchored in the benefits of baking soda and that seems to be resonating with people, both in developed and emerging markets. Femfresh is another one I talked about, which is feminine hygiene. One interesting phenomenon you might be interested in, is there's a lot of product being purchased in Australia and then shipped to China, like the shelves being swept. We're not the only ones that have benefited that from time to time. So that's -- can help -- has helped Australia here and there. is the other one I talked about, so that's the nasal hygiene product. Had fabulous this growth in Mexico this year and France last year behind the strong marketing and lots of new products that we bring out. So it's a nice balance between our export business and our country growth.

componenttext: Great. And then I realize it's early and I'm not going to explicitly ask about gross margins for next year. But maybe as we sort of think about modeling it, are there any one-off type things, benefits, headwinds that would roll off next year that we should think about in modeling?

It's a little early, it's only August but you may be familiar with our evergreen model so every year, we try to expand our operating margins 50 basis points and generally half of that will come from SG&A and half of it from gross margin try to keep marketing pretty level and [indiscernible] price by cutting our advertising. 
There are no further questions. I want to thank you all for dialing in today, and we will talk to you again at the end of October.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I may have asked -- I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I may have asked -- I have been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding, among other things, the company's financial objectives and forecasts. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and other factors that are described in detail in the company's SEC filings. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Mr. Matt Farrell, Chief Executive Officer of Church & Dwight. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. I'm going to start with a brief review of our second quarter results, which you read about in today's press release. I'll then say a few words about our categories before I turn the call over to Rick Di
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. I'm going to start with a brief review of our second quarter results, which you read about in today's press release. I'll then say a few words about our categories before I turn the call over to Rick Dierker. Rick will comment on each of our businesses and review the outlook for Q3 and the full year. And when Rick is finished, I'll get back on. And we'll open the call up for questions.
So here are the highlights. Q2 was a terrific quarter for our company. We posted organic sales growth of 3.7% and 16.4% EPS growth, which is 17.8% EPS growth on a currency-neutral basis. Category growth was broad-based and that 9 of our 15 categories grew in the quarter. From a market share perspective, 4 of our 10 power brands grew share. 
And now, I'll comment on a few of our categories. That will be laundry, litter, vitamins and dry shampoo. The laundry category continues to be healthy, growing 2.5% year-over-year. This is the fifth quarter in a row of laundry category growth. The value segment grew 4%, led by ARM & HAMMER, Simply Tide and Sun. The mid- and premium tier segments grew slower than the category. The laundry category growth was driven by both the unit dose and liquid segments.
Now I'll comment on our 3 laundry brands. ARM & HAMMER has been our big franchise in laundry for many years. ARM & HAMMER laundry share continue to grow this quarter, up 10 basis points. To illustrate the consistency of the brands, ARM & HAMMER's liquid laundry has grown share year-over-year in 26 consecutive quarters. 
Our unit dose products are gaining traction. ARM & HAMMER unit dose in the quarter grew twice the unit dose category growth rate. Our growth was driven by our bi-layer and dual chamber innovations. Growth was equally driven by base and promoted volume, signaling a healthy balance. These are encouraging signs, and we are really pleased with the results. ARM & HAMMER unit dose grew 40 basis points to a 3 share in the quarter. 
Our XTRA brand lost share in the quarter as we continue to see deep competitive discounting. Similar to what we said in Q1, we expect XTRA net sales and profits to increase year-over-year for full year 2016. Oxi laundry share was down 10 basis points year-over-year as we, like others, felt the effect of Persil's promotional activity and increased distribution. As we have said before, we are committed to Oxi laundry detergent and are in this for the long haul.
As you know, Henkel has plans to acquire the Sun products company, which owns all Whisk and Snuggle brands and competes in private label. It's too early to know the impact on the category. There are 2 obvious goals of thought: We may experience a disciplined competitor, who competes with innovation; or the laundry category could see even more discounting. We'll have to just wait and see. Regardless of what happens, we believe our brands are important to consumers. Consumer insights leading to the right products at the right price point will be our formula for success.
Moving on to stain fighters. OxiClean is the leading stain fighter in the additive category. This is the second consecutive quarter that OxiClean's share hit a 48% share, growing 2% versus last year. 
Now I'm going to turn my comments to cat litter. The clumping litter segment is healthy with consumption growth of 4.5%. Q2 saw a significant increase in the amount sold on deal by competitors, notably Clorox and Tidy Cats. At the same time, our amount sold on deal was significantly lower than the prior year, resulting in a pullback in share. In the end, innovation carries the day. We are very pleased with the performance of our new premium priced CLUMP & SEAL MicroGuard. 
And while we're on the topic of innovation, I'd like to acknowledge that ARM & HAMMER CLUMP & SEAL litter received the prestigious 2016 Nielsen Innovation Award for Food and Household Products. CLUMP & SEAL was selected from a field of 3,500 new product launches over a 2-year period. Innovation is the key to long-term organic growth, and we continue to focus on litter innovation.
Now let's talk about vitamins. The overall VMS category continues to show steady growth, up 3%. The Gummy segment of VMS grew at 15% in Q2. Let me break that down for you. The adult Gummy segment grew 21%, while the kids' Gummy segment declined 4%. So vitamins is a good news story for us. Both Vitafusion and Li'l Critters grew in the quarter. Vitafusion adult gummy consumption grew 9%, and Li'l Critters children's gummy also recorded positive growth of 40 basis points. 
Most notable, our combined points of distribution for our vitamin business grew 5% year-on-year, reflecting continued distribution gains. Our strong quarter was the result of new item introductions, expanded distribution of existing SKUs and the quality issues that we experienced last year are behind us. In adult and children's gummy vitamins category, Vitafusion and Li'l Critters are the #1 brands with shares of 31% and 32%, respectively. Adult gummies is where we are putting our focus. It is underdeveloped and will be the source of future growth for us. Remember when we bought the business out of the entire adult VMS category, only 3% was in the gummy form. Today, it is 9%. 
The last category I want to address is dry shampoo. This category grew 28% in Q2 after growing 26% in Q1. The category in the U.S. is now nearly $100 million with the potential to be a $300 million category if we mask the historical category growth experienced in the U.K. where the product originated. 
Batiste is the #1 brand in the U.S., with a 22.3 share. Batiste was the fastest-growing brand in the category, and Batiste original dry shampoo is now the fastest-turning SKU in the category. Batiste global net sales will cross $100 million this year for us, making it the #1 dry shampoo brand globally. And the Batiste brand is expected to be one of our fastest-growing brands in the future. 
Next up is Rick to give you details of our second quarter results and the outlook for Q3 and the full year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. Second quarter reported EPS was $0.85 per share compared to an adjusted $0.73 in 2015, up 16.4%. The $0.85 was better than our $0.79 outlook, largely due to our organic revenue beat and gr
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. Second quarter reported EPS was $0.85 per share compared to an adjusted $0.73 in 2015, up 16.4%. The $0.85 was better than our $0.79 outlook, largely due to our organic revenue beat and gross margin expansion; beat. Netted in that $0.85 is $0.01 or a 1.4% drag from currency year-over-year.
Reported revenues were up 3.6% to $877 million. Organic sales were 3.7%, exceeding our Q2 outlook of approximately 2% to 3%. Our organic sales beat was driven by our consumer business, both domestic and international. This may surprise some of you who track our consumption reports every 2 weeks. The Nielsen and IRI numbers are a barometer of consumption growth. The difference is on measured channels. 
I want to remind everyone about our strength in club and a growing strength of our online business. For example, you read in the release that online sales for our vitamin business doubled. So third-party consumption reporting is directional, but doesn't give the whole picture. 
Now let's review the segments. Consumer Domestic's organic sales increased by 4.4%, driven by Vitafusion gummy vitamins, Batiste Dry Shampoo, OxiClean additives and partially offset by Kaboom cleaners. We continue to expect full year organic sales to be approximately 3% to the domestic business. 
International organic growth was up an impressive 7.4%, driven largely by higher sales in Australia, Mexico and Canada. We are raising our expectation for the full year for organic growth from approximately 5% to 6% to approximately 7% to 8% for the international business. 
For our Specialty Products Division, organic sales were down 7.7%. Milk prices are still relatively low as there is an oversupply globally. And as a result, U.S. exports, which historically have been around 15%-plus of U.S. production, are now around 10%. We are lowering our expectations for the full year for the SPD division to be down 4% to 5%. We like this business, but we do experience these cycles from time to time.
Turning now to gross margin. Our reported second quarter gross margin was 46.5%, a 250 basis point increase from a year ago, which was quite a bit better than we originally expected, largely due to continued improvements in vitamin manufacturing, greater distribution efficiencies and higher personal care sales. Since we spent quite a bit of time last quarter on gross margin, I'd like to break out the detail now for the quarter improvement versus a year ago. I will do the same thing for our full year gross margin outlook in a few minutes.
Q2 gross margin benefited from lower commodities worth 70 basis points. Productivity programs, lower manufacturing costs, which include the absence of vitamin start-up costs, together is worth 130 basis points. Price/volume mix is worth 60 basis points as we had higher personal care organic sales, up almost 8% versus a year ago. And in general, we had a low level of promotion across the portfolio. Finally, we had 20 basis points from the higher margin-acquired businesses offset by a 30 basis point drag from currency. 
Moving to marketing. We increased marketing spend by 3.8% year-over-year. Marketing, as a percent of revenue, was consistent with 2015 at 13.7%. SG&A, as a percentage of net sales, was 12.8%, an 80 basis point decrease from the prior year on a reported basis. Remember in 2015, we had a pension settlement charge of $8.9 million. So on an adjusted basis, SG&A was up 30 basis points, in line with our full year expectations.
Now to operating profit. The reported operating margin for the quarter was 20%, which is 320 basis points higher in the prior year on a reported basis and 220 basis points better on an adjusted basis, largely driven by the gross margin improvement. Other expense was $6.8 million for the quarter. 
Next, our income taxes. Our effective rate for the quarter is 34.7%. We are raising our effective tax rate forecast for the full year to 35%, largely due to geographic mix. So there's a bigger drag from tax.
Turning to cash. We had a strong cash flow quarter. So on a year-to-date basis, we have generated $297 million of cash from operations, which is a $48 million increase from the same period a year ago. So in conclusion, the second quarter highlights include 3.7% organic, 16.4% EPS growth, which again equate to a 17.8% currency-neutral EPS growth.
Turning to the third quarter outlook. We expect Q3 organic sales growth of approximately 1% to 2%, behind stronger promotions and slower growth for our international and SPD divisions. We expect marketing as a percentage of revenue to increase both in dollars and as a percentage of sales as we begin to spend back our gross margin expansion.
We expect third quarter earnings per share of approximately $0.92 compared to $0.90 per share a year ago or a 2% increase year-over-year, which reflects the step-up in marketing, the higher promotional activities, slightly higher SG&A due to incentive comp and a higher tax rate. 
And now turning to the full year. We continue to expect organic sales growth to be 3% to 4%, which has been increased from 3% when we started the year. We posted 4.4% organic growth in the first half. And in the second half, as we plan to spend back a bit more on promotional activities, it results in lower second half organic sales growth. We will likely end up in the middle of the range.
In May, we called approximately 75 basis points of gross margin expansion. And we are pleased to say that we are raising our outlook to 110 basis points of expansion. We can attribute this increase to continued improvements in vitamin manufacturing, greater distribution efficiencies, offset by incremental promotional activities.
I'd like to break out the detail now for the full year gross margin outlook versus a year ago. For the full year, gross margin benefits from lower commodities. And that's worth 60 basis points. Productivity programs, lower manufacturing costs, including the absence of vitamin start-up costs is worth 50 basis points. Price/volume mix is worth 10 basis points as we invest a bit more in higher promotions in the back half. And finally, we forecast 20 basis points from the higher margin acquired businesses, offset by 30 basis point drag from currency. We are increasing our full year marketing expectation by 10 basis points to 12.4% as we spend back some of the gross margin beat. 
Moving to SG&A. Adjusting for the 2015 pension settlement charge, we are now forecasted to increase by 40 basis points. We had previously called 25 basis points for the increase. The higher SG&A rate is due to significantly higher medical costs and higher incentive comp. So now we expect 60 basis points of operating margin expansion for the full year. 
Next is income tax. As I mentioned before, we now expect 35% for the full year, so it's about 30 basis points greater than our previous outlook. In terms of EPS, we dropped the low end of the range and are now targeting 8% to 9% of adjusted EPS growth despite the incremental spending on marketing and promotion as well as the higher tax rate.
We now expect $640 million of operating cash flow, which is $10 million better than our previous outlook of $630 million. We continue to expect $55 million of CapEx for the full year. This equates to $585 million of free cash flow, which represents 125% plus of free cash flow conversion. 
Wrapping up, as you read in our earnings release today, we also announced the 2-for-1 stock split of our common stock. The split will increase our total shares outstanding from approximately 128.8 million and 257.6 million shares.
Now, Matt and I will open it up for questions.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, I wanted to start, or Rick as well for that matter, on the guidance. So organic sales stays the same. Gross margin's a bit better. But Matt, it seems like -- and then advertising and marketing moves up more modestly. So it seems like you're probably
componenttext: Matt, I wanted to start, or Rick as well for that matter, on the guidance. So organic sales stays the same. Gross margin's a bit better. But Matt, it seems like -- and then advertising and marketing moves up more modestly. So it seems like you're probably leaning a bit harder on trade spend in coupon with some of this gross margin upside relative to taking up advertising and marketing. Is that correct? I just wanted to get some additional thoughts on how you're sort of balancing the trade spend in advertising and marketing.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Matt and I can both answer that. But Kevin, from a financial perspective, I'd say it's pretty broad-based. We have higher promotional spending. Yes, we also have higher advertising, so I think it's a combination. And that's kind of the -- again broa
componenttext: Well, Matt and I can both answer that. But Kevin, from a financial perspective, I'd say it's pretty broad-based. We have higher promotional spending. Yes, we also have higher advertising, so I think it's a combination. And that's kind of the -- again broad-based across advertising and promotional spending.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin. Just to give you maybe a little more color. In my remarks, I said, "Hey, there's a lot of discounting going on in laundry and litter."  And in litter, for example, we actually pulled back on trade promotions year-over-year in Q2. While at the
componenttext: Yes, Kevin. Just to give you maybe a little more color. In my remarks, I said, "Hey, there's a lot of discounting going on in laundry and litter."  And in litter, for example, we actually pulled back on trade promotions year-over-year in Q2. While at the same time, if you looked at Tidy Cat or Fresh Step, they were up significantly in Q2. And even in laundry, the amount sold on deal for ARM & HAMMER was actually lower year-over-year in Q2. Whereas if you looked at Tide, Simply Tide or Sun or -- and especially, Purex, they're way up in amounts sold on deal year-over-year. So every quarter is different. You got to react to what's going on in the marketplace. And as I said, we want to stay behind OxiClean. OxiClean laundry, we're in for the long haul there. And here and there in some other categories, there's some competitive moves that we need to react to. So fortunately, we have financial flexibility in order to do that. And as you know, we got a big portfolio of brands, so we're in a position where we need some help -- we're going to put the help there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. That makes sense Rick, I wanted to come back to -- you touched on a little bit some of the nonscan channel growth versus the scanned or tracked channel growth. And so you're up about 0.5 point in the Nielsen data for the second quarter. T
componenttext: Okay. All right. That makes sense Rick, I wanted to come back to -- you touched on a little bit some of the nonscan channel growth versus the scanned or tracked channel growth. And so you're up about 0.5 point in the Nielsen data for the second quarter. That implies very strong double-digit growth in nontracked, just using sort of back-of-the-napkin sort of map based on reasonable assumptions for channel mix. So can you guys help me a bit? What is online now as a percent of sales and understanding that the club is not the Nielsen data as well? But curious what that number is if you care to share it. What do your market shares look like online versus nontracked? Proctor talks about having higher market share in the online channel relative to more traditional mass channels. And then Matt, maybe touch on a little bit, if this continues to evolve and the consumer continues to move online, talk about the implications a bit for your business from even broadly margin perspective. It's seemingly less trade spend at this point, et cetera.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Kevin, just to touch briefly we don't really go into the details of our online sales. We said historically, it's 1% to 3% of sales just like any other CPG companies, that's true. I'd say it's fast growing. From a market share perspective, we don'
componenttext: Sure. So Kevin, just to touch briefly we don't really go into the details of our online sales. We said historically, it's 1% to 3% of sales just like any other CPG companies, that's true. I'd say it's fast growing. From a market share perspective, we don't really comment on that either. What I will do for you though is help you with the tracked versus nontracked. And there's 2 or 3 drivers on that disconnect. For example, there's probably around 200 basis points from club and online, plus the fact that Batiste isn't really tracking Nielsen data in the reports you guys get. There's also a disconnect when you don't spend on promotion. So for example, XTRA, consumption's down 6%. Our net sales is essentially flat because we're not spending as deeper on promotions. Same thing with SPINBRUSH, which we talked about before as well. We're up 10% consumption, net sales are up 15%. So when you're trying to bridge consumption all the way back to organic, those are a couple of the reasons why. And I'll turn it back to Matt for online.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just broadly, as Rick said that most consumer products companies have sales between 1% and 3% online. And online is actually not as clear as you might think in order to determine shares because you got Amazon and Walmart.com, Target.com. There's l
componenttext: Yes, so just broadly, as Rick said that most consumer products companies have sales between 1% and 3% online. And online is actually not as clear as you might think in order to determine shares because you got Amazon and Walmart.com, Target.com. There's lots of places where we want our product to be available. And the whole game is you want your product to be ubiquitous, right? It needs to be wherever a consumer wants to find it. So we need to -- we're looking at this as just another class of trade. We have a convergence going on between research and advertising. So a lot of the research now, a lot of consumer behavior research is digital. It's online. Same time, a lot of the advertising is online. So we're -- we understand that we're weaving both our advertising and our research efforts together as a result. It's the early innings for everybody. And everybody's going to look at, do we have the right pack sizes for online? You're going to have different packs online than you have in the store just to take the weight up. We always look at change. It's our friend because we're a small company. So we think that we can react to change a lot faster than other companies. So we're kind of looking forward to competing online.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The organic growth guidance for the third quarter, was there a timing shift in shipments at all? Or is it merely a function of higher promotional spending, which is going to take the gross to net down? Because the comps [indiscernible] in the third quarte
componenttext: The organic growth guidance for the third quarter, was there a timing shift in shipments at all? Or is it merely a function of higher promotional spending, which is going to take the gross to net down? Because the comps [indiscernible] in the third quarter than the second quarter obviously.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a couple of things. I mean, what you're going to do is also just deceleration from first half to second half. The incremental promotional spending, right, that's one, we're up against higher comps for vitamin, like for example, our perso
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a couple of things. I mean, what you're going to do is also just deceleration from first half to second half. The incremental promotional spending, right, that's one, we're up against higher comps for vitamin, like for example, our personal care growth was up big in Q2, up 8% organically. Remember vitamins, we were cutting a year ago in Q2, and that kind of lessened as we got in the back half. And then category comps for laundry, for example, are up a little bit in the back half. And then international growth, the first half was a 10% and the full year is at 78, so that implies a second half of 4% to 5%. So all those reasons are why we're decelerating a little bit. But I'd say that's our original outlook was 3%. We always thought it would be -- we raised that in the beginning of the year to 3% to 4%. And we always know it can be a little bit lumpy.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I mean but how have the comps been harder in this quarter than they are for next quarter. Because all that stuff is good, but like in aggregate, the comp's like 200 basis points easier than the comp in the second quarter. You know what I mean?
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I mean but how have the comps been harder in this quarter than they are for next quarter. Because all that stuff is good, but like in aggregate, the comp's like 200 basis points easier than the comp in the second quarter. You know what I mean?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the other comment I'd make is the laundry category -- going back to category dynamics for a second. If you go back to 2015, the laundry category was actually down in Q1, right? And in 2016, the laundry category was up in Q1. So on a stacked b
componenttext: Well, I mean the other comment I'd make is the laundry category -- going back to category dynamics for a second. If you go back to 2015, the laundry category was actually down in Q1, right? And in 2016, the laundry category was up in Q1. So on a stacked basis, that was around 5%. In Q2, it's around 4%. But then when you look out, the laundry category actually had 2% to 3%, almost 4% growth in the back half of the year in 2015. So now part of it is, like I said before, household comparisons for laundry and then personal care -- really vitamins going from Q2 to the back half is a more difficult comp.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just directionally, is it fair to think that like the personal care business has 20 gross margin points higher than the household business? Is that a safe assumption? I'm just trying to calculate the mix impact of the business shift.
componenttext: Okay. And then just directionally, is it fair to think that like the personal care business has 20 gross margin points higher than the household business? Is that a safe assumption? I'm just trying to calculate the mix impact of the business shift.

componenttext: Yes, we've said that probably before. We said personal care margins are about 2,000 basis points better than household.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to clarify, as I look forward, as you're spending back in some of these brands, has that always kind of been in the plan of, "Hey, we just kind of get to midyear and look to redeploy in certain areas? And then specifically, is what you're seeing
componenttext: Just want to clarify, as I look forward, as you're spending back in some of these brands, has that always kind of been in the plan of, "Hey, we just kind of get to midyear and look to redeploy in certain areas? And then specifically, is what you're seeing in liquid laundry in terms of the price competition or some of the rollbacks what you expected or has competition heated up a little bit?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if -- I'd say competition has heated up because of the amount sold on deal. It's certainly higher than it was year-over-year. Sequentially, it's probably consistent with the first quarter. The way we run the business, Bill, is we put a range
componenttext: I don't know if -- I'd say competition has heated up because of the amount sold on deal. It's certainly higher than it was year-over-year. Sequentially, it's probably consistent with the first quarter. The way we run the business, Bill, is we put a range out there, 7% to 9%, so we're pretty much targeting the midpoint of our range generally. And we get a great first half, so we say, "Hey, we don't see our way to 7%," so we're going to say we'll come in and take the bottom of the range, so call it, 8% to 9%. And we don't try to hit the home run in any 1 year. We're always thinking about the next year. So we want to make sure we're positioned well going into next year. So to the extent we have the dough, we're going to spend it back. And this has been a perennial move on the part of Church & Dwight.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I appreciate that. I think I have a previous handle on the trends. But I was trying to kind of more understand as you look to the back half, I understand the strategy of spending back. But is there an incremental need to spend back in liquid laundry a
componenttext: No, I appreciate that. I think I have a previous handle on the trends. But I was trying to kind of more understand as you look to the back half, I understand the strategy of spending back. But is there an incremental need to spend back in liquid laundry and/or cat litter versus what can you originally expect to start the year?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, because we -- I would say that because we pulled back on a percentage of sale on deal for litter in the second quarter, I'd say that's something we would try to remedy in the back half because obviously, we lost some share there. But shares can be a
componenttext: Yes, because we -- I would say that because we pulled back on a percentage of sale on deal for litter in the second quarter, I'd say that's something we would try to remedy in the back half because obviously, we lost some share there. But shares can be a sawtooth, right? It can go up and down, but I will say that it's definitely competitive in litter, both Tidy Cat and Clorox spending a lot of dough promoting their products. So we'll obviously have to react to that, but laundry is our biggest category. And that's one we'll also to react. XTRA continues to lose share. We're managing that for profit, but there is a line that we won't cross, right, so we have to make sure we shore that up in the second half.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just switching kind of -- Rick, I think you talked about the Nielsen IRI doesn't track your stuff perfectly. And then I understand that, especially coming for vitamins, which kind of where the business was built out of club and mask. But ca
componenttext: Okay. And then just switching kind of -- Rick, I think you talked about the Nielsen IRI doesn't track your stuff perfectly. And then I understand that, especially coming for vitamins, which kind of where the business was built out of club and mask. But can you talk about other wins or other kind of growth you're seeing outside of vitamins in the club channel or the online channel? And where you feel pretty good about?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean other online brands, it's very strong as TROJAN, for example. That helped lead to the personal care organic growth in Q2. Across the board in oral care has been pretty strong as well. So that's happening on club, online. Those are 2 examples.
componenttext: Yes, I mean other online brands, it's very strong as TROJAN, for example. That helped lead to the personal care organic growth in Q2. Across the board in oral care has been pretty strong as well. So that's happening on club, online. Those are 2 examples. But again, it's -- we  don't get all -- we're all about tracked versus nontracked. It's -- a piece of it is the whole concept of promotional volume and not chasing that promotional volume. That causes a little bit of a disconnect between organic and consumption.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Bill, as you know, personal care products lend themselves more to online sales than the heavy litter and detergent products.
componenttext: Yes. And Bill, as you know, personal care products lend themselves more to online sales than the heavy litter and detergent products.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Caroline Levy with CLSA.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just if you could talk a little more in detail on the share movement. So I know you've touched on some of this already. But I guess, 6 of 10 categories, you didn't gain share, which is unusual. Were some of those flat? And then what are the plans across t
componenttext: Just if you could talk a little more in detail on the share movement. So I know you've touched on some of this already. But I guess, 6 of 10 categories, you didn't gain share, which is unusual. Were some of those flat? And then what are the plans across the board to turn those around for the things you haven't talked about yet?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Well, the 4 that we're up were Oxi Stain Fighter, Nair, Batiste and vitamin. So the other ones, we might talk about, SPINBRUSH, for example. That category, battery-operated toothbrushes, was up 9.5%. Our adult toothbrush was up 10%. But our kid
componenttext: Yes, okay. Well, the 4 that we're up were Oxi Stain Fighter, Nair, Batiste and vitamin. So the other ones, we might talk about, SPINBRUSH, for example. That category, battery-operated toothbrushes, was up 9.5%. Our adult toothbrush was up 10%. But our kids was soft. So sort of a balance there, it's where we fell back. XTRA, we talked about, and obviously, deep discounting there, particularly from the part of Sun products and some Simply Tide as well. Orajel, the issue there was private label, had a good quarter. Condoms, that kind of ebbs and flows, so we generally don't worry too much about the condom share because we have approximately 75 share in that category. First Response though, there's been a lot of couponing and competition that we have to address. So some of that, by the way, for the earlier questions is pregnancy kits is also an area that we're putting some money behind in the second half because we lost some share as a result of competition in the second quarter. And the ARM & HAMMER brand, in total, all forms was down driven by litter. So it was down slightly. If it's all forms, about 10 basis points. But it was really litter that was the driver there. So that's sort of the rundown on the 10 brands, Caroline.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And does that -- is that why you're getting more aggressive? Was that really driving the change? Or is it simply you have the money to spend? Because I mean you generally love to claim that almost all of your categories are gaining share. So is tha
componenttext: Right. And does that -- is that why you're getting more aggressive? Was that really driving the change? Or is it simply you have the money to spend? Because I mean you generally love to claim that almost all of your categories are gaining share. So is that the goal by year-end? You want to be up in all categories?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, when we say 4 out of 10, it's not like we're unhappy. I don't think we've ever had a 10 out of 10 quarter. I think 6 would be great, 6 out of 10. And if the rest were around flattish. So yes, I mean, some of them are -- they're clearly issues i
componenttext: Yes. Look, when we say 4 out of 10, it's not like we're unhappy. I don't think we've ever had a 10 out of 10 quarter. I think 6 would be great, 6 out of 10. And if the rest were around flattish. So yes, I mean, some of them are -- they're clearly issues in each of those different brands. But we expect to remedy them in the third and fourth quarter.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So think of it -- it's not just the U.K. We have a European business, that's our #1 subsidiary, followed by Canada, which is #2. But they also have STERIMAR, which is a feminine hygiene brand and -- or pardon me, femfresh was a feminine hygiene brand; and then STERIMAR, which is our nasal hygiene brand. So they've been doing extremely well.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then lastly, just on your margin profile online. Is there any degradation of margin as you build up that business?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, some of the products that we sell online can be higher margin than they are in bricks and mortar. So it's a balance right now. We're pretty happy with the margins online. I think the heavier products like litter is where we would be more pressed
componenttext: Actually, some of the products that we sell online can be higher margin than they are in bricks and mortar. So it's a balance right now. We're pretty happy with the margins online. I think the heavier products like litter is where we would be more pressed on margin. They'd be lower than anything we would have in bricks and mortar.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but overall, even online, personal care mix is slanted toward personal care, so it helps the margin as well. So we're happy with that.
componenttext: Yes, but overall, even online, personal care mix is slanted toward personal care, so it helps the margin as well. So we're happy with that.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Joe Altobello with Raymond James.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll just -- I'll pick up there on the gross margin guide and I apologize if I missed this. Was mix the biggest driver of the upside to the full year?
componenttext: I guess I'll just -- I'll pick up there on the gross margin guide and I apologize if I missed this. Was mix the biggest driver of the upside to the full year?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the full year, I would probably say partly mix, but also because of the organic revenue growth on personal care. But I'd also say we are pleasantly surprised as we're turning the corner on our vitamin manufacturing and our vitamin distribution efficien
componenttext: To the full year, I would probably say partly mix, but also because of the organic revenue growth on personal care. But I'd also say we are pleasantly surprised as we're turning the corner on our vitamin manufacturing and our vitamin distribution efficiencies. A year ago, when we were cutting customers, the trucks were going out everyday and they weren't always filled, right? Because we wanted to get that next shipment to the retailer as soon as possible. When we look back to this quarter, for example, our fill rate's closer to 99%. So we're shipping out full truckloads again. So that's -- and that's an example what's going on with gross margin.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then in terms of the third quarter, the organic, up 1% to 2%. If you look at your volume growth the last few quarters, it kind of averaged somewhere between 3% and 4%. So maybe if you could deconstruct for us what you're thinking
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then in terms of the third quarter, the organic, up 1% to 2%. If you look at your volume growth the last few quarters, it kind of averaged somewhere between 3% and 4%. So maybe if you could deconstruct for us what you're thinking in terms of volumes versus price mix in the third quarter. Is it volumes up 2% to 3%, call it, maybe price mix down 1%?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, I think you're very familiar with the story. And we're -- we've been a perennial volume company. I think this past quarter, we had some positive price mix as well and that was because we had lower promotions. It was -- but I'd say for the go for
componenttext: Yes, Joe, I think you're very familiar with the story. And we're -- we've been a perennial volume company. I think this past quarter, we had some positive price mix as well and that was because we had lower promotions. It was -- but I'd say for the go forward, it's typically always volume so that's how I would look at it. And then as we're spending back a little bit incrementally on promotions or whatnot, that might be a flat to slightly negative drag for pricing.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I just asked because -- and this has been brought up previous earnings call. But if you look at the third quarter compare for volumes, it's fairly easy, much easier than the second quarter. So that's why I was trying to look at those 2 drivers. But
componenttext: Okay. I just asked because -- and this has been brought up previous earnings call. But if you look at the third quarter compare for volumes, it's fairly easy, much easier than the second quarter. So that's why I was trying to look at those 2 drivers. But on the SG&A upside, it sounds like it's more of the same, what you guys talked about last quarter, which is investments and things like sales and IT, et cetera.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean that's what the difference between our original outlook of minus 10 to plus 25 basis points of spending. And that was really the conversation last quarter for the full year. Now that incremental 15 basis points is higher medical costs, right,
componenttext: Yes, I mean that's what the difference between our original outlook of minus 10 to plus 25 basis points of spending. And that was really the conversation last quarter for the full year. Now that incremental 15 basis points is higher medical costs, right, just like many other companies were self-insured. And every now and then, we have catastrophic events that we have to cover. And then plus higher subcomp. Gross margin's doing really well, so is cash flow. And we feel good about the outlook.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also want to go back to your guidance on gross margins for the 110 basis point improvement this year, the expectation. Just want to get a sense as you look at that improvement, is there anything that you consider unsustainable? And I guess then, potenti
componenttext: I also want to go back to your guidance on gross margins for the 110 basis point improvement this year, the expectation. Just want to get a sense as you look at that improvement, is there anything that you consider unsustainable? And I guess then, potentially, the new base of gross margins you expect this year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean the only thing -- again, to break out the 110, we said it was 60 for commodities, 50 for lower manufacturing costs, 10 for price volume mix, 20 from really the new acquisitions and the 30 basis point drag for FX. The commodity stuff, we're sta
componenttext: Yes, I mean the only thing -- again, to break out the 110, we said it was 60 for commodities, 50 for lower manufacturing costs, 10 for price volume mix, 20 from really the new acquisitions and the 30 basis point drag for FX. The commodity stuff, we're starting to lap. And that really started a year ago in August, so back half 2015. So that's not sustainable for go-forward future. So that's always a risk. Lower manufacturing costs, I think we do a great job in this company with our productivity program. And that's really -- that leads into our kind of operating model. Price/volume mix, so typically we're volume grower. We don't really take price in a lot of categories. Acquisitions, that's all dependent on kind of what we do buy. Typically, we do recently, but personal care-type businesses were higher margins. And then, of course, the currency as we lap that drag, hopefully, that will be a little bit more benign. So hopefully that gives you some color, Rupesh.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And if I could ask one more question. If you look at the overall environment out there, a number of retailers, especially on the grocery side, I missed their comp numbers this past quarter. Just want to get a sense of how you guys are thinkin
componenttext: Okay, great. And if I could ask one more question. If you look at the overall environment out there, a number of retailers, especially on the grocery side, I missed their comp numbers this past quarter. Just want to get a sense of how you guys are thinking about the current environment out there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is a question we get all the time. What's our perspective on the consumer? And I'm not going to tell you anything you haven't read in The Wall Street Journal. So we keep an eye on employment rates, median household income. You can see oil is go
componenttext: Well, this is a question we get all the time. What's our perspective on the consumer? And I'm not going to tell you anything you haven't read in The Wall Street Journal. So we keep an eye on employment rates, median household income. You can see oil is going down again. It dipped below 40 this week. So obviously, that's good from a disposable income standpoint. But the issue is GDP, right? So GDP is some of the banks are calling it 1.5% for the U.S. this year. So you don't have -- and you don't have significant population growth. So everybody is struggling to find growth in the U.S. And oftentimes, the suppliers producers resort to price if they don't have innovation. So it's sort of a -- that's what we're looking at right now, Rupesh.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had one last question on the promotional environment. So I guess laundry more so than litter is probably a category where when commodity costs improve, you've seen the environment flare up over time. So a couple of questions. One, would you say there ar
componenttext: I had one last question on the promotional environment. So I guess laundry more so than litter is probably a category where when commodity costs improve, you've seen the environment flare up over time. So a couple of questions. One, would you say there are other categories in your portfolio where you feel like they're more commodity sensitive vis-√†-vis promotional activity? And that sort of this change in environment maybe should have been anticipated or in your outlook to begin with? Luckily, you've got plenty of wiggle room to deal with it. And then secondly, same would be on litter. Just a standpoint, you knew this Clorox was launching. I would actually think that maybe it was intentional to step back less than spend a bunch and then kind of when that quieted down, to get more active. So it just -- the pattern of promotional activity didn't strike me as necessarily surprising in litter. And then just at laundry, you think is more commodity-related than anything else.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lauren, did you say you were surprised by the promotional activity in litter?
componenttext: Lauren, did you say you were surprised by the promotional activity in litter?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'm not actually at all, yes.
componenttext: No, I'm not actually at all, yes.

componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Because actually, we have Tidy Cat getting behind their lightweight variant, and Clorox has their litter with Febreze right...
componenttext: Yes, okay. Because actually, we have Tidy Cat getting behind their lightweight variant, and Clorox has their litter with Febreze right...

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just so you'd be tactical on your part, right? Like the other 2 have a lot of noise like let them promote their noise. And then you'd kind of take a break and come -- and then come back into the market.
componenttext: Yes, just so you'd be tactical on your part, right? Like the other 2 have a lot of noise like let them promote their noise. And then you'd kind of take a break and come -- and then come back into the market.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. So we had pulled back on amounts sold on deal in the second quarter for litter, and we lost some share. Okay, that's fine. It's not like we're surprised by that. But it's -- 1 quarter doesn't make a year. Your question is if you think about our v
componenttext: Exactly. So we had pulled back on amounts sold on deal in the second quarter for litter, and we lost some share. Okay, that's fine. It's not like we're surprised by that. But it's -- 1 quarter doesn't make a year. Your question is if you think about our various categories, so there are a lot of categories that are sensitive to commodities. I would say it's -- other than laundry, that's where all the questions go and why, because we're worried about surfactants and ethylene prices and resin, et cetera. If you're thinking about all the commodities that we sweat -- I'm just going to run down on this. So surfactants, which is derived from ethylene and then your -- and then you have resin, right? Diesel, which is going to affect our transportation cost but that affects everything. Latex for condoms but that's actually a small part of the cost of goods sold. And then you have paper, right, so we have so many things that are packaged in paper board. So -- and then you get a lot smaller after that, soda ash, which is pretty tepid right now, and things like palm fatty acid distillate. So we would say, with the exception of laundry, there aren't a lot of categories we would say are going to be dramatically affected by commodities.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Lauren, I would add 2 things. Number one, I wouldn't expect -- our comments on promotional volume isn't really saying we're going to spend a lot of money back in the laundry category to drive promotions. We're going to continue to support OxiClean Lau
componenttext: And Lauren, I would add 2 things. Number one, I wouldn't expect -- our comments on promotional volume isn't really saying we're going to spend a lot of money back in the laundry category to drive promotions. We're going to continue to support OxiClean Laundry. Right now let's look at the data, our amounts sold on deal, just in total, is lower than a year ago or right at levels of a year ago. So we're not throwing a whole ton of money back into -- across the brand. The other thing I'd say, just from a commodity perspective, commodities are starting to inch up. So we've said previously in Q1 and Q2, for example, that resin was down 10%. Surfactants were down 20%, and that was true. The second half, we're starting to lap those comparisons. So resin will likely be closer to flat, and surfactants will probably be closer to up slightly just for context.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Powers with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Powers with UBS.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: I guess, first, just one more cleanup if I could on organic growth guidance for Q3. You get to increase promotional investment, and I'm sure, it's all, to some extent, conservative. But you call out in the release a more difficult year-over-year comparison in international specifically. And again, my numbers could be incorrect but looks like both the 1- and a 2-year comps actually get sequentially easier in Q3 versus Q2. So can you just comment there if there's something that I'm missing on that are specifically concerned about lapping.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're exactly right. I think our comment started off at a country or 2. Australia, for example, has a high comp. And that evolved to a one-liner in the release. But international, as I said before, the first half was really 10% growth. And so
componenttext: No, I think you're exactly right. I think our comment started off at a country or 2. Australia, for example, has a high comp. And that evolved to a one-liner in the release. But international, as I said before, the first half was really 10% growth. And so with the full year at a 7% to 8%, and that means that second half is going to be closer to 4%, 5% that's really the context you should think of for international growth for the year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then, I guess, more kind of more broadly, I think it was back at your Analyst Day in January, you've spent some time talking about distribution wins that you've been making over the past 3, 4, 5 years. I just wonder if you
componenttext: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then, I guess, more kind of more broadly, I think it was back at your Analyst Day in January, you've spent some time talking about distribution wins that you've been making over the past 3, 4, 5 years. I just wonder if you could weigh in a little bit on how much of the strength you've seen in this year is aided by even more distribution wins. And I'm guessing it's pretty broad based where you're seeing it. But just if you can comment on which businesses you're having -- those wins are having the most impact. I'm assuming it's things like vitamins and Batiste, but again, some context there would be helpful.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, there's no question you hit the 2 that are leading the pack. And one is vitamins, where as I said in my opening remarks, that we have 5% increase in distribution, which is pretty significant because obviously, that carries over into future quarte
componenttext: Yes, no, there's no question you hit the 2 that are leading the pack. And one is vitamins, where as I said in my opening remarks, that we have 5% increase in distribution, which is pretty significant because obviously, that carries over into future quarters. And then Batiste is just a craze. So it's getting more and more shelf space and when you're the -- there are more and more retailers becoming more interested in it. So it seems like almost every quarter now, we're gaining more distribution, and that has compounding effect that's why we -- although it's a small brand, we continue to talk about it because it is influencing our numbers. So you've hit on the 2 big ones there.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, okay. So some carryover into next year. And then back to the questions on the volume trajectory, which we've -- there's been a few, right? But you are suggesting that volume decelerates on both the sort of a standalone and 2-year stack basis
componenttext: Got it. Okay, okay. So some carryover into next year. And then back to the questions on the volume trajectory, which we've -- there's been a few, right? But you are suggesting that volume decelerates on both the sort of a standalone and 2-year stack basis, particularly on 2-year stack, pretty substantially despite the incremental spend. So implicitly, you seem to be suggesting that you're not expecting a lot of volumetric response to the incremental promotional dollars you're putting into market. Is that a fair interpretation? And if so, why?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. I think I went into the detail of why it's not just the incremental promotional spending up against some higher comps for vitamins and the category counts for laundry, for example, and the whole international strong growth, the
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things. I think I went into the detail of why it's not just the incremental promotional spending up against some higher comps for vitamins and the category counts for laundry, for example, and the whole international strong growth, the deceleration. We're spending quite a bit of money back on marketing, right? And that's going to take some time to really pull through demand. On incremental trade and really couponing spending, those investments are really to drive trial for new products. That's the crux of it. And so we want to get that repeat rate up. And it's too early to call volume upside from driving trial. So that really -- we're just really in the process, Jason. And we think that when we get back up to our competitor's levels of promotion and just on par with what we had a year ago even, we think that will be a nice momentum as we exit 2016.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to add to that, Jason. If we went to the first quarter in 2015, the laundry category declined, round numbers, 1.5%. And then first quarter '16, it was up 6.5%. So on a stack basis, I know a lot of people like to talk on a stack basis, you'd say
componenttext: Yes, just to add to that, Jason. If we went to the first quarter in 2015, the laundry category declined, round numbers, 1.5%. And then first quarter '16, it was up 6.5%. So on a stack basis, I know a lot of people like to talk on a stack basis, you'd say laundry was up 5% on a 2-year basis. And Q2 on a 2-year basis stack, it was 4%. If you go to 3 and 4 last year, Q3 was 2.5%, and Q4 was 3.5%. So that would suggest you're going to see deceleration in laundry if you're a believer in the stack theory. And if we think it's going to be around from 4% to 5%, we're seeing a deceleration in the laundry category on a year-over-year basis. So who knows? That's just math. But it's something to think about.

componenttext: Well, with respect to what our sales are by country, we wouldn't get into that. And this is kind of anchored in the benefits of baking soda. That seems to be resonating with people, both in developed and emerging markets. femfresh is another one I talked about, which is feminine hygiene. One interesting phenomenon you might be interested in is there's a lot of product being purchased in Australia and then shipped to China, like the shelves being swept. We're not the only ones that have benefit of that from time to time. So that's -- can help -- has helped Australia from here and there. STERIMAR is the other one I talked about, so that's a nasal hygiene product -- had fabulous growth in Mexico this year and France last year behind a strong marketing and lots of new products that we bring out. So it's a nice balance between our export business and our country growth.

componenttext:
It's a little early, it's only August. But you may be familiar with our evergreen model. So every year, we try to expand our operating margins 50 basis points. And generally, half of that will come from SG&A and half of it from gross margin. We're going to try to keep marketing pretty level and not save our way to prosperity by cutting our advertising. 
All right, there are no further questions. I want to thank you all for dialing in today. And we'll talk to you again at the end of October.
