headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Caroline Levy of CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question is from Caroline Levy of CLSA.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I noticed that 4 of your 10 power brands had shaken. But it seems to be a number that's coming down over time. And just wondering what gives you -- or where would you expect that number to be a year from now? What -- obviously, the goal is 10 out of 10. B
componenttext: I noticed that 4 of your 10 power brands had shaken. But it seems to be a number that's coming down over time. And just wondering what gives you -- or where would you expect that number to be a year from now? What -- obviously, the goal is 10 out of 10. But what are you -- what do you believe you can change to make that a different number?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've had 4 this quarter, 4 last quarter. And as you know, we're far more transparent than other CPG companies, and then we call out our brands. And then we give ourselves a report card and let our analysts and investors know as well. So the 4 that w
componenttext: Yes, we've had 4 this quarter, 4 last quarter. And as you know, we're far more transparent than other CPG companies, and then we call out our brands. And then we give ourselves a report card and let our analysts and investors know as well. So the 4 that were up were Batiste, VMS, OxiClean and Nair. Seems okay were the other 6. So one was flat, and that was ARM & HAMMER. So we had growth in laundry, but that was offset by litter. So if you said, where is that one that you would expect to improve next year? Yes, it would be ARM & HAMMER. So that 4 would become 5. So then you say, what are the other ones? The other ones would be TROJAN. And yes -- so in TROJAN, we had lost some share in measured channels, but we had strong growth in untracked channels and that will continue to be probably a bigger part of the discussion, measuring brand growth in measured channels versus all-in, which is harder to get your arms around. XTRA is certainly one that we've been suffering because of deep competitive discounting. So it's been more or less in the sidelines there. So that one, we expect to turn around, and obviously, it's pretty obvious what that's going to take. Orajel, there's been some pressure from private label, but we have an improved product offering that's coming out in Q4 to distinguish ourselves again further from private label. So we hope that's going to have a positive impact. First Response, the issue there is we have some retailers experimenting with the split between branded and private label. And SPINBRUSH, last quarter, adult grew 10% and kids were soft. This quarter, it's the reverse. Kids was way up and adult was soft. But the business grew, just not as the same pace as the category. So it's a mixed bag. As we said, what would be a good score? Every quarter would be -- we'd say 6. If you could get 6 out of 10 every quarter, that would be fantastic. And I think stellar would be 7 to 8. But 9 to 10 is aspirational, Caroline.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Yes. Jumping into international. If you're guiding to 9% sales growth for the year, which I think you are, that would be a big slowdown in the fourth quarter. Is there something there?
componenttext: Got it. Yes. Jumping into international. If you're guiding to 9% sales growth for the year, which I think you are, that would be a big slowdown in the fourth quarter. Is there something there?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Caroline, we've incorrectly called this for 2 or 3 quarters. We kept on thinking international would come back down to earth and be mid-single digits. And I think we just maybe called it a little too early can. And so this is really just the reality
componenttext: Yes. Caroline, we've incorrectly called this for 2 or 3 quarters. We kept on thinking international would come back down to earth and be mid-single digits. And I think we just maybe called it a little too early can. And so this is really just the reality of -- that business is a great business. And we think we're going to grow mid-single-digits for a long time. On the edges, Europe is slowing down a little bit and Australia as well. But in general, 5% -- 4%, 5% in Q4 is still a solid growth number.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we should expect long term that if we're calling 3% for the company that we would expect the international business to be higher than that year-after-year.
componenttext: Yes, and we should expect long term that if we're calling 3% for the company that we would expect the international business to be higher than that year-after-year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then lastly, it's a little more detail. But you said a lot about laundry, but I'm asking if you could tell us a little bit more about specifically what you think the acquisition of Sun might do? What you're actually seeing, if you're seeing an
componenttext: Got it. And then lastly, it's a little more detail. But you said a lot about laundry, but I'm asking if you could tell us a little bit more about specifically what you think the acquisition of Sun might do? What you're actually seeing, if you're seeing anything yet, out of Procter? Are they stepping up their promotional activity? What's changing there?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't take a swing at that one, Caroline, so I wouldn't comment on what's going on with Henkel and Sun. I mean, they just closed the acquisition. But I haven't seen anything different as far as discounting goes. They're discounting heavily all year
componenttext: Yes, I can't take a swing at that one, Caroline, so I wouldn't comment on what's going on with Henkel and Sun. I mean, they just closed the acquisition. But I haven't seen anything different as far as discounting goes. They're discounting heavily all year long, Purex and Sun. So there's been no change to that since acquisition.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Jason Gere of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Jason Gere of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, some CPG companies have been talking about seeing some retailer destocking. So I was just wondering, is there anything that you've been seeing in any of your FDM customers at this point.
componenttext: I guess, some CPG companies have been talking about seeing some retailer destocking. So I was just wondering, is there anything that you've been seeing in any of your FDM customers at this point.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, you do hear that from time to time over the years, but I don't think that ever happens. And I think the retailers are as focused on working capital as anybody else. So I think they run a pretty tight ship. So it's unusual to have a situation w
componenttext: No. I mean, you do hear that from time to time over the years, but I don't think that ever happens. And I think the retailers are as focused on working capital as anybody else. So I think they run a pretty tight ship. So it's unusual to have a situation where a retailer is overstocked and they're cutting back on their inventories.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question, I know you mentioned TROJAN before. Just been seeing some of these articles out there talking about millennials don't like condoms. So just wondering how do you respond to that and in terms of growing that business and wh
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question, I know you mentioned TROJAN before. Just been seeing some of these articles out there talking about millennials don't like condoms. So just wondering how do you respond to that and in terms of growing that business and what do you see on your end.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always going to be a certain percent of the population that doesn't enjoy sex with a condom. But that's been a great business for a long period of time. We got a 75% share. And being the big dog in the category, it's up to us to continue to
componenttext: Well, there's always going to be a certain percent of the population that doesn't enjoy sex with a condom. But that's been a great business for a long period of time. We got a 75% share. And being the big dog in the category, it's up to us to continue to promote safe sex and compliance.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Olivia Tong of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Olivia Tong of Bank of America.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in Q4, you're looking for a 1% to 2% organic sales growth. So obviously, implied in that guidance is the potential that there could be acceleration from Q3. So can you talk about what gives you confidence in seeing that potential acceleration? Are ther
componenttext: So in Q4, you're looking for a 1% to 2% organic sales growth. So obviously, implied in that guidance is the potential that there could be acceleration from Q3. So can you talk about what gives you confidence in seeing that potential acceleration? Are there incremental programs going in place? Obviously, you've got a little bit of step down in comps, but that didn't quite help that much in Q3. So can we talk about that first please?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's a couple of things. Number one, we don't have the tactical couponing on OxiClean in the same degree that we did in Q3. We don't have the impact to the Orajel product returns/recall. On a positive note, our vitamin business and our laundry
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's a couple of things. Number one, we don't have the tactical couponing on OxiClean in the same degree that we did in Q3. We don't have the impact to the Orajel product returns/recall. On a positive note, our vitamin business and our laundry business had some promotions in Q4, but some of them were in Q3 a year ago. So we feel pretty good about the 2.5% that we call for the Consumer Domestic division. That's probably where your head's around.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then just on the dry shampoo, you guys have talked a little bit about the $300 million opportunity if you can get to the U.K. level. So can you talk about the similarities you see between the 2 markets? And then how much of that growth that y
componenttext: Perfect. And then just on the dry shampoo, you guys have talked a little bit about the $300 million opportunity if you can get to the U.K. level. So can you talk about the similarities you see between the 2 markets? And then how much of that growth that you've seen so far is new distribution versus the underlying strength within the category? And if it does continue to grow at these levels, what about the competitive threat from others entering the category and potentially chipping away your share?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. So here's a way to think about it. There are about 60 million people in the U.K. And in U.S. dollars, the consumption of dry shampoo is about $60 million. So when we look at the U.S., we say, hey, we still got 335 million people in the
componenttext: Yes, good question. So here's a way to think about it. There are about 60 million people in the U.K. And in U.S. dollars, the consumption of dry shampoo is about $60 million. So when we look at the U.S., we say, hey, we still got 335 million people in the U.S. where we, too, have similar used consumption in the U.S., you'd have a $300 million category. So it is as simple as that. As far as where is the growth coming from, it's not simply -- it is new distribution, but it's higher consumption. The category continues to grow. And the good news for us is that the category is growing rapidly. And our share keeps expanding. So our share expanded from Q2 to Q3 in a category that's growing rapidly. And what we have going for us is that Batiste is a European brand, number one. And number two, that exceeds far better than anything else that's on the market. So it's really product performance is what's winning. So people who have not used our product and then switch to Batiste, they don't go back. So it's -- we're not concerned about other entrants. There are a lot of people in there already, right? Not Your Mother's, TRESemm√©, et cetera. So there's plenty of big dogs in the category. So we certainly like our chances. We're #1 dry shampoo globally, not just in the U.S.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Rupesh Parikh of Oppenheim.
componenttext: Our next question is from Rupesh Parikh of Oppenheim.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions were answered. But one I wanted to ask on the M&A front. You're clearly in the public market, so we've seen some of the froth come out of consumer staples valuation. I was just curious, as you guys are looking out there, are you seein
componenttext: Most of my questions were answered. But one I wanted to ask on the M&A front. You're clearly in the public market, so we've seen some of the froth come out of consumer staples valuation. I was just curious, as you guys are looking out there, are you seeing better valuation or better opportunities out there in M&A search?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a hard one to answer. I wouldn't say I can make any sweeping comment about multiples of going up or down. As you know, we are an inquisitive company, so anything that is for sale in CPG, 99 out of 100 times, we will get the book. But I wouldn'
componenttext: Yes, that's a hard one to answer. I wouldn't say I can make any sweeping comment about multiples of going up or down. As you know, we are an inquisitive company, so anything that is for sale in CPG, 99 out of 100 times, we will get the book. But I wouldn't say that the market has peeled off or gotten any worse.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then going back to Specialty Products Division. Clearly, the dairy market challenges has been an issue weighing on that business. Are there any other competitive dynamics that play in terms of the weakness that you've been seeing?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then going back to Specialty Products Division. Clearly, the dairy market challenges has been an issue weighing on that business. Are there any other competitive dynamics that play in terms of the weakness that you've been seeing?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's a good question. So it's not a function of losing share. It's entirely due to demand. The interesting thing about that business is that once a dairy farm starts using your product, and particularly, the ARM & HAMMER. So one of the products we s
componenttext: No, that's a good question. So it's not a function of losing share. It's entirely due to demand. The interesting thing about that business is that once a dairy farm starts using your product, and particularly, the ARM & HAMMER. So one of the products we sell under the ARM & HAMMER name is -- and it creates a lot of -- there's a lot of weight that goes with that. So once you're with the producer, they're going to stick with you. So it's not switching or share. It's just purely demand.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our last question is from Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Just 2 quick questions. Are you guys seeing any activity with the retailer kind of prompting more promotional activity on behalf of the suppliers? Meaning, kind of the, what I call, the retailer reach back given some of the traffic issues they're dealing with in the face of the economy and also e-commerce. That's the first question. And then the second question is just thinking about the international business. What's the -- like the vision and the strategy on that business? I mean, are you going to take kind of like a coax approach and just focus on a couple of countries? Or do you believe that you have some more whitespace opportunity to expand your footprint?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll stick to international one, first. So we have a business in Mexico and Brazil. So we'd like to go where the people are, right? So there's over 100 million people in Mexico, and there's 200 million in Brazil. So those will be a focus for us. And
componenttext: Yes, we'll stick to international one, first. So we have a business in Mexico and Brazil. So we'd like to go where the people are, right? So there's over 100 million people in Mexico, and there's 200 million in Brazil. So those will be a focus for us. And then there are countries where we're not in like Germany for example, which is the largest, strongest economy in Europe. So longer term, we'd say, yes, that's a place we'd want to be in. And then export is one that is just a fountain for us, because we have found that our products do travel well, and we have built an export team with great leadership there, and we think the sky's the limit with respect to driving our product internationally. So I think that's sort of the view with respect to international, Nik. That's why we're so positive about it. Your front-end question was, have we seen more asks on the part of the retailers?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I've been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding, a
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Church & Dwight Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, I've been asked to remind you that on this call, the company's management may make forward-looking statements regarding, among other things, the company's financial objectives and forecasts. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and other factors that are described in detail in the company's SEC filings. 
I would now like to introduce your host for the call, Mr. Matt Farrell, Chief Executive Officer of Church & Dwight. [Operator Instructions] Sir, please go ahead.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. I'll provide some color on the quarter and then turn the call over to Rick Dierker. When Rick is finished, we'll open the call up for questions. So Q3 was a solid quarter for our company. EPS e
componenttext:
Okay. Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. I'll provide some color on the quarter and then turn the call over to Rick Dierker. When Rick is finished, we'll open the call up for questions. 
So Q3 was a solid quarter for our company. EPS exceeded our outlook. Organic sales growth of 1.2% was in line with our August outlook of 1% to 2%. We would've been at the high end of the range if not for a far-worse than expected result in our animal nutrition business which was an unexpected 70 basis points drag on the outlook. The quality of earnings was high this quarter. We expanded gross margin. We invested in higher marketing of 50 bps and SG&A was lower year-over-year. We overcame a high tax rate, a small product recall, and a big decline in our animal nutrition business and still beat our EPS outlook by $0.01. Our consumer business delivered volume-driven organic sales growth of 2.5%, but by continued strong growth by our international consumer business. In the U.S., our organic sales growth met our expectations reflecting higher couponing, as we communicated back in August. The good news is, category growth was broad-based. 10 of our 15 categories grew in the quarter. 
Now, I'm going to say a few words about 4 of our categories. 
The laundry category continues to be healthy, growing 4% year-over-year and our laundry business grew with the category. This is the sixth quarter in a row of laundry category growth driven by both the unit dose and liquid segments. 
In liquid laundry detergent, this quarter marked the 27th consecutive quarter of share growth for ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry. In contrast, our XTRA  brand lost share in the quarter as we continued to see deep competitive discounting. Similar to what we said in Q2, we expect XTRA net profits to increase year-over-year for full-year 2016 and we have plans to turn around that brand. Also in the liquid category, OxiClean grew share to 1.8%, driven by strong promotional support. As we have said before, we are committed to OxiClean laundry detergent. We are encouraged by the trial activity in this most recent quarter and our repeat rate continues to improve. 
Turning to the unit-dose segment. Our unit dose products continue to gain traction and had some of the largest gains in the category. For the second consecutive quarter, ARM & HAMMER unit dose grew twice the unit dose category growth rate and our growth was driven by our bi-layer and dual chamber innovations. Most important, our unit dose business was equally driven by base and promoted volume with signaling a healthy balance. ARM & HAMMER unit dose grew 50 basis points to 3.2 share in the quarter. Similarly, OxiClean unit dose also grew share in the quarter and is now a 1.1 share. These are encouraging signs as we continue to go in the right direction. 
Finally, in fabric care, the stain-fighter category grew 3.2%; OxiClean grew consumption 7% and is the leading stain-fighter in the additive category with the 48% share. OxiClean grew share 170 basis points in the quarter.
The litter category continues to be very competitive with increased couponing. For the quarter, the litter category was up 3.7% while our brands were flat in measured channels. Our shipments were up as our online litter business more than doubled. Long term, we have won in this category through innovation which continues to be our focus.
Now, we'll talk about vitamins. The overall VMS category continues to show steady growth, up 3.8%. The gummy 
[Audio Gap]
percent compared to a 5% decline in the category. This is the second consecutive quarter that we have outpaced the children's gummy category. Today, the gummy form of the entire adult VMS category is 10%. It was 3% when we bought the business 4 years ago. Vitafusion and Li'l Critters are the #1 brands with shares of 28% and 30% in measured channels, respectively. Adult gummies is where we are putting our focus. It is underdeveloped and will be the source of future growth for us. 
The last category I'll address is dry shampoo. This category grew almost 27% in Q3 after growing 26% in Q1 and 28% in Q2. The category in the U.S. is now over $100 million with the potential to be a $300 million category if we max the historical category growth experienced in the U.K. where the product originated. Batiste is the #1 brand in the U.S., with a 23.6% share. The Batiste brand is expected to be one of the fastest growing brands in the future for us. 
Now I'm going to talk about international. Our international consumer business has emerged as a growth driver for Church & Dwight. After growing 3% to 4% annually from 2011 to 2014, our international business grew 8% in 2015, and is expected to hit 9% in 2016. 
Batiste is only part of the story. Many brands have contributed to the success story. We have enjoyed stellar growth in Europe, Canada and Mexico this year, while our export business continues to open new doors for our brands. We look forward to steady, strong growth from the international business in the future. 
Our Q3 total company organic growth was held back by significantly lower volume in our animal nutrition business, which reflects depressed milk prices. When we began the year, we expected full year growth from this business to be 1% to 3%, and now we're expecting a 9% decline on a full-year basis. That is quite a reversal. Thanks to the strength of our consumer business, we expect to deliver 8% EPS growth and 3% organic growth for full year 2016. 
We've said we're early in our 2017 planning process. We'll say more about that in February. But for now, we again expect high single-digit EPS growth next year. 
Next up is Rick to give you details about third quarter results, the outlook for Q4 and the full year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. Third quarter reported EPS was up 4.4% to $0.47 per share compared to $0.45 in 2015, which was $0.01 ahead of our $0.46 outlook. Reported net sales were up 1% to $871 million. Organic sale
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everybody. I'll start with EPS. Third quarter reported EPS was up 4.4% to $0.47 per share compared to $0.45 in 2015, which was $0.01 ahead of our $0.46 outlook. Reported net sales were up 1% to $871 million. Organic sales growth of 1.2% was in line with our 1% to 2% range, but at the lower end, dragged down by the 70 basis point hit from our SPD business. When we spoke to you in August, we assumed a 3% decline in that business versus the 11% decline we experienced. 
Now let's review the segments. Consumer Domestic's organic sales increased by 0.8% in the quarter. Volume growth was solid at 2.1%, offset by 1.3% drag from pricing. Now we expected approximately 1% organic for that business as we had anticipated the incremental coupon to support our new products and Q4 promotional shifts. As mentioned, we were a little below 1% as we also got hit with returns due to a small product recall from our Orajel business. 
I know you guys are a fan of stack numbers, so I wanted to call out our volume results. For Q3, of the 3.5% stack organic, all of it is volume. Looking ahead to Q4. We expect organic sales to be 2.5% for the domestic business. That translates to maintaining our full year organic sales outlook of 3%. 
Consumer International organic growth was up an impressive 12.1%. Batiste continues to build depth of distribution in many countries. OxiClean and ARM & HAMMER continue to expand in North America, and TROJAN continues to do well in Latin America. We're raising our expectation for the full year organic growth from 7% to approximately 9% for the international business. 
To recap, 3% for the Consumer Domestic business for the full year and 9% for the Consumer International business equates to 4% full year growth for the global consumer business, and we are really pleased with that result. 
For our SPD division. Organic sales were down 11.5%. Milk prices continue to be low due to an excess global supply of milk and weak exports due to a strong dollar. As said in the past, we like this business but we do experience these cycles from time to time. On the bright side, the industry does forecast a slight improvement in milk prices in 2017. 
Turning now to gross margin. Our reported third quarter gross margin was 45.4%, a 60 basis point increase from year ago, primarily due to lower commodities and our productivity programs. Q3 gross margin benefited from lower commodities worth 40 basis points. Productivity programs and lower manufacturing costs, worth 60 basis points. We also had 30 basis points from higher-margin acquired business, and going the other way, we had a drag of 50 basis points from price/volume mix as we had those higher promotional investments, largely the couponing we discussed earlier, plus we had a 20 basis points drag from currency. 
Now moving to marketing. We increased marketing spend by 5.8% year-over-year. Marketing as a percent of net sales increased 50 basis points to 11.3%. SG&A as a percentage of net sales was 11.6%, a 30 basis point decrease from the prior year. This decline was primarily due to the timing of R&D spend and lower litigation costs. 
Now on to operating margins. The reported operating margin for the quarter was 22.5%, which is 40 basis points higher than the prior year. And the other good news is that as a proxy for cash earnings, our EBITDA margin was up to 26% in the quarter. 
Next, income taxes. Our effective rate for the quarter is 35.6%, and we continue to expect our full year rate to be 35%. 
Turning to cash. We had a really strong cash flow quarter. On a year-to-date basis, we have generated $495 million of cash from operations, an $86 million increase from the same period a year ago, primarily due to higher cash earnings and improved working capital. 
So in conclusion, the third quarter highlights include a strong consumer organic growth rate of 2.5%, increased gross margin expansion as we exceeded our outlook by $0.01, even after absorbing a hit from the SPD revenue decline and a small product recall. 
Turning now to the fourth quarter outlook. We expect Q4 organic sales growth of approximately 1% to 2%. The consumer business is expected to pick up steam in the fourth quarter at 2.5% organic growth while we expect the dairy business to be down 13% and a drag on the total company organic sales growth. We expect fourth quarter earnings per share of approximately $0.42 compared to $0.41 a share a year ago or a 2% increase year-over-year. 
For context, the significant year-over-year decline in SPD revenues equates to $0.01 drag to the EPS line, and we also have a higher tax rate that equates to about $0.01. You may recall that Q4 2015 tax rate has a full year R&D credit all in one quarter. 
Turning to the full year. We now expect organic sales growth to be at the lower end of our 3% to 4% range, which reflects the previously discussed headwind from our Specialty Product Division. We continue to expect gross margin expansion of 110 basis points due to continued lower commodity costs and greater distribution efficiencies. And we also continue to expect 60 basis points of full year operating margin expansion and to deliver 8% EPS growth. 
Finally, we now expect $650 million of operating cash flow and $50 million of CapEx for the full year. This equates to $600 million of free cash flow, which represents over 125% free cash flow conversion. 
Now Matt and I will open it up for questions.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I tried to do that in my script the last few quarters. But continued improvement from commodities was worth 40 basis points. Productivity, manufacturing improvements was worth 60 basis points. Negative price point in mix was a drag of 50 basis
componenttext: Yes, sure. I tried to do that in my script the last few quarters. But continued improvement from commodities was worth 40 basis points. Productivity, manufacturing improvements was worth 60 basis points. Negative price point in mix was a drag of 50 basis points, and that's largely the couponing that we talked about, and that's for the whole company. Acquisitions was worth 30 basis points, higher-margin businesses, and then a drag of 20 basis points for FX. Now as you know, the commodity benefit will start to continue to go down, and that's in our expectations for Q4. For example, commodity by -- commodities by itself, Q1 was a benefit of 120 basis points; Q2, 70 basis points; Q3, 40 basis points; and we expect 10 basis points in Q4.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And I know we're not going to get into a lot of detail in '17 yet, but you did put some numbers out there this morning. And in there, you talk about ongoing progression in gross margins expected for next year. What are some of the puts and
componenttext: That's helpful. And I know we're not going to get into a lot of detail in '17 yet, but you did put some numbers out there this morning. And in there, you talk about ongoing progression in gross margins expected for next year. What are some of the puts and takes that give you confidence in your ability to get there, given that, as you just pointed out, the commodity tailwind should be dissipating?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're exactly right. In general, for commodities next year, we think it's pretty benign, with the exception of surfactants, which is going to be up, we believe, in 2017. But remember, we have our Evergreen productivity program, and that's re
componenttext: Yes. I think you're exactly right. In general, for commodities next year, we think it's pretty benign, with the exception of surfactants, which is going to be up, we believe, in 2017. But remember, we have our Evergreen productivity program, and that's really the driver behind gross margin expansion all the time, and sometimes that's masked by the commodity impact.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kevin Grundy of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kevin Grundy of Jefferies.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, I wanted to start on the SPD business. And I guess, just given what milk prices did there, a disappointing result, does a quarter like this give you any pause with respect to the fit in the portfolio? I think your commentary in the past has been aro
componenttext: Matt, I wanted to start on the SPD business. And I guess, just given what milk prices did there, a disappointing result, does a quarter like this give you any pause with respect to the fit in the portfolio? I think your commentary in the past has been around a relatively comparable margin profile, somewhat attractive return on operating asset kind of business. But I guess, the rebuttal would be, it seems to be noncore and arguably a distraction. If investors wanted exposure to dairy prices, they could do so by investing in other assets. And I guess, more fundamentally, a concern could potentially be that from 1 quarter to the next, you could be in a position where you're faced with pulling back on investment behind a mega brand as milk prices tank in order to hit the guide on the quarter. So if you could revisit, I guess, some thoughts there and whether a quarter like this gives you any pause, that'd be helpful. And I have a follow-up.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin. That's a good question. I'm sure a lot of people are clutching their hearts because the business had such a falling off this quarter versus even our expectations when we spoke to everybody in August. But we do take the long view on this busine
componenttext: Yes, Kevin. That's a good question. I'm sure a lot of people are clutching their hearts because the business had such a falling off this quarter versus even our expectations when we spoke to everybody in August. But we do take the long view on this business. So we don't look at it as simply a -- the dairy business that it is today, and it is one dimensional. And it's largely doing business in the U.S. and largely in dairy. But we have changed the focus of that business from simply dairy to animal productivity. And what we did was we bought this business 1.5 years ago called VI-COR, in early 2015. And then what that did was that got us into poultry, swine and cattle and also some international products. So it got us exposure to other species. So we want to even out the cycles over time by growing into other species and also with more acquisitions. So you might say, well, if I want to invest in an animal productivity business, I can go to Sawedis [ph] or one of these other companies. And I would say, look, this is an asset-light business. We have the good fortune of the legacy business of this company, which is sodium bicarbonate, having more out of that into animal productivity. And we have a lot of science in that part of the company, which is probably not well understood, Ph.D. chemists, veterinarians, et cetera. So we have a great nucleus of people to build upon. And because it's asset-light, because you know we're a cash-driven company, it has all the characteristics we want to grow over time. And the big macro is you've got 7 billion people today, going to 9 billion in 2050. So it's a long answer, but it probably deserves a long answer considering the fact that it influenced the numbers this quarter. Now looking ahead to '17. The good news is the milk prices are forecasted to start recovering next year. So it's not going to be as bad next year as this year. So we would expect some growth out of this Specialty Products business in '17, but it's certainly a legitimate question, Kevin.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Matt. And a follow-up here. The consumer organic sales guidance for 4Q, if I'm not mistaken, is 2.5%. And even -- so when I take a look at the comps, that still implies some slowing in the fourth quarter. Can you talk a little bit about what's drivi
componenttext: Okay, Matt. And a follow-up here. The consumer organic sales guidance for 4Q, if I'm not mistaken, is 2.5%. And even -- so when I take a look at the comps, that still implies some slowing in the fourth quarter. Can you talk a little bit about what's driving that? The Personal Care number was a little bit weak in third quarter. I don't know if there's an expectation that persists. And then what exactly is driving that dynamic? Is there more couponing and heavier trade spend, given what's going on in laundry right now, where that's ramped? So just if you could help sort of -- help me understand a bit what's driving the 2-year average sort of slowdown into the fourth quarter as well.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Kevin, it's Rick. Now remember a couple of things here. We had a great VMS second half in 2015, right? We had recovered in a big way from all the cuts we experienced in the back half of '14 and early '15. So the back half was like 5.5% growth f
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Kevin, it's Rick. Now remember a couple of things here. We had a great VMS second half in 2015, right? We had recovered in a big way from all the cuts we experienced in the back half of '14 and early '15. So the back half was like 5.5% growth for example, and the first half was flat. So to some degree the comps were influenced by -- the slowdown was influenced by that. That's number one. Number two, we do have some incremental couponing to drive trial. That was largely a Q3 event, but we do have a little bit in Q4. And in general, Q4 going to 2.5% organic is predominantly a volume-driven result. And there's a little bit of price mix in there too. But personal care growth, which was a little bit negative in Q3, is expected to recover and be slightly positive in Q4 as well. So I hope that helps. It's a little bit more color.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

So our view is that when we have innovation, and you know us, we do always have something coming, that's the time to promote heavily. But we're not part of the war right now.

componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then just -- it's kind of a new business you guys haven't really talked about, but this export business, I mean, is it as simple as that like you kind of load up like a 40-foot container and ship a bunch of products to some country where you don't have a discrete sales force or am I missing something?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You obviously, had a college job on the docks. No. Look, we're doing what a lot of businesses did 20, 30 years ago. We have a -- it's not just export, it's -- the international team is extremely strong. We have a strong management team, with some new gene
componenttext: You obviously, had a college job on the docks. No. Look, we're doing what a lot of businesses did 20, 30 years ago. We have a -- it's not just export, it's -- the international team is extremely strong. We have a strong management team, with some new general managers in a couple of countries. And we've been able to grow international through a combination of local brands and U.S. brands. In North America, ARM & HAMMER and OxiClean and TROJAN are doing really well in Canada and Mexico. Even a more recent acquisition, you remember those vaginal moisturizers we bought, REPHRESH and REPLENS, doing well in Europe. But in export, we've been adding people and resources in Central America and in Southeast Asia that opens up a lot of new countries for us. And yes, sure, I mean, as far as the manner in which you ship, certainly we're shipping to distributors around the world. But we've got a terrific distributer network out there. And that's one of the strengths of that business.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Chapelle of SunTrust.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Bill Schmitz's. So if you're not -- if couponing is not really around litter, I mean, is it -- and you were talking about new products that it is focused, is it primarily around pods? I mean, is that the big focus?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Bill Schmitz's. So if you're not -- if couponing is not really around litter, I mean, is it -- and you were talking about new products that it is focused, is it primarily around pods? I mean, is that the big focus?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, here's the way to think about it when you think about laundry. So liquid laundry detergent had the highest percentage sold on deal as a category in the past 2 years and in Q3. We were significantly under that. So we've -- we have not ramped it up
componenttext: Yes. No, here's the way to think about it when you think about laundry. So liquid laundry detergent had the highest percentage sold on deal as a category in the past 2 years and in Q3. We were significantly under that. So we've -- we have not ramped it up, we've had steady amounts sold on deal for ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry for the past couple of quarters. The same is true for unit dose. In my remarks, what I said was that unit dose is growing, and it's balanced between the on deal and base. So where the couponing is for us is in OxiClean. So OxiClean, as you know, we launched a couple of years ago. And then Persil came on the scene, then we went sideways for a while. So we've had to work a lot harder to get trial, and it's been working for us, but it's been costly. So the couponing that we're referring to is largely for OxiClean in laundry.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Rick, on the gross margin bridge that you walked through. Where would I -- I mean, both on the kind of the easier comparisons from the vitamin start-up. And then also, I assume there was a mixed benefit from the decline in specialty that,
componenttext: Okay. And then, Rick, on the gross margin bridge that you walked through. Where would I -- I mean, both on the kind of the easier comparisons from the vitamin start-up. And then also, I assume there was a mixed benefit from the decline in specialty that, that would have actually helped gross margin with -- Is that right? And would that fall in -- where would that fall in, in that bridge?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You're exactly right, Bill, on both counts. Well, remember, the VMS start-up expenses really did start to dissipate as we got into Q3 and Q4 a year ago. Those were predominantly even more help in Q2. And remember, we had 130 basis points in Q2 a year
componenttext: Yes. You're exactly right, Bill, on both counts. Well, remember, the VMS start-up expenses really did start to dissipate as we got into Q3 and Q4 a year ago. Those were predominantly even more help in Q2. And remember, we had 130 basis points in Q2 a year ago -- last quarter as a manufacturing benefit. This quarter, it was only 60 [ph] basis points, because we -- those start-up expenses did dissipate a year ago. As far as mix for actual division mix, yes, you're right. The decline in SPD probably threw off around --I don't know, 10, 15 basis points, and that would be in the mix line.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last one for me. Matt, I guess in 2 out of the past 3 years I think, you've done ASRs for your shares. And just because cash was sitting on the sidelines, I know it was a good use of it, why just this authorization today? And then in kind o
componenttext: Okay. And then last one for me. Matt, I guess in 2 out of the past 3 years I think, you've done ASRs for your shares. And just because cash was sitting on the sidelines, I know it was a good use of it, why just this authorization today? And then in kind of your initial guidance for next year of high single-digit EPS growth, is there an assumption of a lower share count? Or is that not factored in yet?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that, Bill. It's -- generally, what we've done in the past few years, between $200 million to $400 million of share buyback, right? And our authorization, we only had about $130 million left. And so just typically this year, we do our plann
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that, Bill. It's -- generally, what we've done in the past few years, between $200 million to $400 million of share buyback, right? And our authorization, we only had about $130 million left. And so just typically this year, we do our planning cycle. We go to the board and say, hey, here's our refresh for our share authorization. In the last 2 years, we've done $500 million. We're doing $500 million again. So that's kind of a consistent approach. It doesn't mean we're going to do $500 million. I will say that if we will be selective, depending on what the share price is, to either ramp that up or ramp that down. But we do have an assumption of the share count in our plan, and we'll go through that probably in February.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And ASRs are still possible?
componenttext: And ASRs are still possible?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: ASRs are possible. The 10b5-1s are also possible. It just depends.
componenttext: ASRs are possible. The 10b5-1s are also possible. It just depends.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Powers of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Powers of UBS.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to go back again to Bill Schmitz's litter question and just carry forward the logic of your answer. You might not be the primary actor today, but if you've always got something new coming to promote behind, it would follow that you've probably got
componenttext: So just to go back again to Bill Schmitz's litter question and just carry forward the logic of your answer. You might not be the primary actor today, but if you've always got something new coming to promote behind, it would follow that you've probably got something new coming in cat litter and therefore, might that not be just the catalyst for the current battles to continue? Or is -- I guess, to Bill's question, is there something that breaks the cycle?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steve, part of it is we believe innovation wins, right? At the end of the day, the product sells itself. And so you have to do trial. You have to do everything else to promote your product and get it in the hands of consumers. But at the end of the d
componenttext: Yes. Steve, part of it is we believe innovation wins, right? At the end of the day, the product sells itself. And so you have to do trial. You have to do everything else to promote your product and get it in the hands of consumers. But at the end of the day, our belief in litter, and that's why we didn't even exist in 1990s in litter and we're up to the #2 brand in litter today, it's innovation. And so all this price competition is what it is. And we're kind of holding our own, right? Sales are slightly up in the quarter despite all this amount sold on deal and couponing. But we believe innovation trumps all of that.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And I know the pressures that led to the lower guidance this quarter were really Specialty Products-related. But just taking a step back and listening to the full slate of CPG [ph] companies that have reported so far, it seems like dema
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And I know the pressures that led to the lower guidance this quarter were really Specialty Products-related. But just taking a step back and listening to the full slate of CPG [ph] companies that have reported so far, it seems like demand trends remain broadly challenged. Competitive pressures are rising, and they're rising certainly more so in certain pockets, but broadly, they're rising. And deflationary benefits are turning into inflationary pressures as you look forward. And altogether, that's not really a great combination. So I guess, I'd just love your perspective on that, again, broadly speaking. And then specific to your business, I think, how those dynamics impact laundry -- is probably the most critical factor as you think about '17. So if there's a way for you to focus your comments on how they're shaping your 2017 planning in that category? Specifically, that would be great as well.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steve, this is probably a better question to ask first week of February because then we'll be talking about what innovation we have by category for next year. Because as you know, CPG business is a shelf space game, right? So the more shelf space, th
componenttext: Yes. Steve, this is probably a better question to ask first week of February because then we'll be talking about what innovation we have by category for next year. Because as you know, CPG business is a shelf space game, right? So the more shelf space, the more market share. And you need innovation to bump the other guy off the shelf and take more share and get more facing. So it's an innovation story, frankly, for 2017. And that's why we would have the confidence to say, hey, we're going to hit our Evergreen model again in 2017. Your larger question might be about the economy. And of course, we see everything that you see, right? Unemployment is pretty steady, but GDP is only 1.5%. And gasoline price is creeping up. Health care costs are noticeably increasing for consumers. And the median household income around $51,000. So that is the consumer. So obviously, that's hitting the consumer in the pocketbook. So it's -- I wouldn't say it's the best outlook for the consumer. But from our point of view, we think that we have so many different ways to win here. And we have -- we get 10 brands. We've got a great international business. And Specialty Products has its ups and downs, but that'll be back next year. So it's going to have a 12-cylinder engine. And as we showed in this quarter, some of them are misfiring, others will. And we're able to hit our numbers. So we aim to hit the numbers again next year just as we did this year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve, I want to add to that is, Matt had the comments -- commentary. But laundry category, up 4%, still strong. Vitamin category, up 10%, great tailwind. Batiste category, up 20%. So there's a lot of good things happening despite in some other catego
componenttext: And Steve, I want to add to that is, Matt had the comments -- commentary. But laundry category, up 4%, still strong. Vitamin category, up 10%, great tailwind. Batiste category, up 20%. So there's a lot of good things happening despite in some other categories where there's more competitive pressure.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. That's all fair. That's all fair. And then -- and I may have missed this, but is there any -- did you call out any early indication on the stock option compensation accounting change and how that's going to impacts -- impact your tax rate and e
componenttext: Yes. Okay. That's all fair. That's all fair. And then -- and I may have missed this, but is there any -- did you call out any early indication on the stock option compensation accounting change and how that's going to impacts -- impact your tax rate and earnings algorithm next year?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't done it yet. It's a pretty simple calculation, but we'll probably do that next quarter and give you guys an outlook on that specific piece of it.
componenttext: No, we haven't done it yet. It's a pretty simple calculation, but we'll probably do that next quarter and give you guys an outlook on that specific piece of it.

componenttext: Our next question is from Joe Altobello of Raymond James.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to international, and I'm looking at the hockey stick that you guys alluded to earlier, beginning in '15 and now '16 in terms of organic growth. I'm trying to tease out, I don't know if this is the way to do it, how much of that growt
componenttext: Just want to go back to international, and I'm looking at the hockey stick that you guys alluded to earlier, beginning in '15 and now '16 in terms of organic growth. I'm trying to tease out, I don't know if this is the way to do it, how much of that growth is coming from sort of like-for-like same-store sales? And how much of that is coming from expanded distribution of certain brands?

componenttext: Are you talking about country by country now?

componenttext: No, no. Just in general. Just in general. The [indiscernible] that you're looking at today, how much of that is a like-for-like growth number?

componenttextpreview: Yes, the predominant of that is like-for-like growth, right? We are in existing countries. We're doing depth of distribution for Batiste. ARM & HAMMER is doing great in Canada and Mexico, right? So it's an existing -- it's in our existing footprint.
componenttext: Yes, the predominant of that is like-for-like growth, right? We are in existing countries. We're doing depth of distribution for Batiste. ARM & HAMMER is doing great in Canada and Mexico, right? So it's an existing -- it's in our existing footprint.

componenttext: Yes, Joe. It was the -- for the export business, that would be new doors, new shelves in countries, right? That's the expanding piece of it.

componenttext: Okay. So in terms of the impact on the P&L, I mean, what's the margin impact from that faster growth in international? What's the drag?

componenttext: Why do you think there's a drag from that, Joe?

componenttext: I would just assume there would be a drag. I would assume your Consumer Domestic business would be a more profitable business.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember, as we're growing internationally, a lot of those sales, remember are personal care and nature versus the household and nature. So yes, we have household products in Canada and Mexico, but export business is predominantly more like a Batiste or a
componenttext: Remember, as we're growing internationally, a lot of those sales, remember are personal care and nature versus the household and nature. So yes, we have household products in Canada and Mexico, but export business is predominantly more like a Batiste or a femfresh, which is personal care margin. So you're right, it has a bigger distributor margin. So at the net, you have a lower number, but it's on par because of PC brands.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly on laundry, you mentioned 4% category growth despite pretty significant couponing going on there. How much of that is coming from the base liquid business? And how much of that is from unit dose and people using more product in the
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly on laundry, you mentioned 4% category growth despite pretty significant couponing going on there. How much of that is coming from the base liquid business? And how much of that is from unit dose and people using more product in the unit dose category?

componenttext: Well, unit dose is the bigger grower of the 2 versus the liquids...

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Caroline Levy of CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question is from Caroline Levy of CLSA.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I noticed 4 of your 10 power brands had share gains. But it seems to be a number that's coming down over time. And just wondering what gives you -- or where would you expect that number to be a year from now? What -- obviously, the goal is 10 out of 10. B
componenttext: I noticed 4 of your 10 power brands had share gains. But it seems to be a number that's coming down over time. And just wondering what gives you -- or where would you expect that number to be a year from now? What -- obviously, the goal is 10 out of 10. But what are you -- what do you believe you can change to make that a different number?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've had 4 this quarter, 4 last quarter. And as you know, we're probably more transparent than other CPG companies, in that we call out our brands. And then we give ourselves a report card and let our analysts and investors know as well. So the 4 th
componenttext: Yes, we've had 4 this quarter, 4 last quarter. And as you know, we're probably more transparent than other CPG companies, in that we call out our brands. And then we give ourselves a report card and let our analysts and investors know as well. So the 4 that were up were Batiste, VMS, OxiClean and Nair. So you'd say, okay, what are the other 6? So one was flat, and that was ARM & HAMMER. So we had growth in laundry, but that was offset by litter. So if you said, where -- is there one that you would expect to improve next year? Yes, it would be ARM & HAMMER. So that 4 would become 5. So then you say, what are the other ones? The other ones would be TROJAN. And yes -- so in TROJAN, we had lost some share in measured channels, but we have strong growth in untracked channels and that will continue to be probably a bigger part of the discussion, measuring brand growth in measured channels versus all-in, which is harder to get your arms around. XTRA is certainly one that we've been suffering because of deep competitive discounting. So it's been more or less in the sidelines there. So that one, we expect to turn around, and obviously, it's pretty obvious what that's going to take. Orajel, there's been some pressure from private label, but we have an improved product offering that's coming out in Q4 to distinguish ourselves again further from private label. So we hope that's going to have a positive impact. First Response, the issue there is we have some retailers experimenting with the split between branded and private label. And SPINBRUSH, last quarter, adult grew 10% and kids were soft. This quarter, it's the reverse. Kids was way up and adult was soft. But the business grew, just not at the same pace as the category. So it's a mixed bag. If you said, what would be a good score? Every quarter would be -- we'd say 6. If you could get 6 out of 10 every quarter, that would be fantastic. And I think stellar would be 7 to 8. But 9 to 10 is aspirational, Caroline.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Yes. Jumping to international. If you're guiding to 9% sales growth for the year, which I think you are, that would be a big slowdown in the fourth quarter. Is there something there?
componenttext: Got it. Yes. Jumping to international. If you're guiding to 9% sales growth for the year, which I think you are, that would be a big slowdown in the fourth quarter. Is there something there?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Caroline, we've incorrectly called this for 2 or 3 quarters. We kept on thinking international would come back down to earth and be mid-single digits. And I think we just maybe called it a little too early. And so this is really just the reality of -
componenttext: Yes. Caroline, we've incorrectly called this for 2 or 3 quarters. We kept on thinking international would come back down to earth and be mid-single digits. And I think we just maybe called it a little too early. And so this is really just the reality of -- that business is a great business. And we think going to grow mid-single-digits for a long time. On the edges, Europe is slowing down a little bit and Australia as well. But in general, 5% -- 4% or 5% in Q4 is still a solid growth number.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we should expect long term that if we're calling 3% for the company that we would expect the international business to be higher than that year-after-year.
componenttext: Yes, and we should expect long term that if we're calling 3% for the company that we would expect the international business to be higher than that year-after-year.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then lastly, it's a little more detail. But you've said a lot about laundry, but I'm asking if you could tell us a little bit more about specifically what you think the acquisition of Sun might do? What you're actually seeing, if you're seeing
componenttext: Got it. And then lastly, it's a little more detail. But you've said a lot about laundry, but I'm asking if you could tell us a little bit more about specifically what you think the acquisition of Sun might do? What you're actually seeing, if you're seeing anything yet, out of Procter? Are they stepping up their promotional activity? What's changing there?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't take a swing at that one, Caroline. I wouldn't comment on what's going on with Henkel and Sun. I mean, they just closed the acquisition. But I haven't seen anything different as far as discounting goes. They've been discounting heavily all ye
componenttext: Yes, I can't take a swing at that one, Caroline. I wouldn't comment on what's going on with Henkel and Sun. I mean, they just closed the acquisition. But I haven't seen anything different as far as discounting goes. They've been discounting heavily all year long, Purex and Sun. So there's been no change to that since the acquisition.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Jason Gere of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Jason Gere of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, some CPG companies have been talking about seeing some retailer destocking. So I was just wondering, is there anything that you've been seeing at any of your FDM customers at this point.
componenttext: I guess, some CPG companies have been talking about seeing some retailer destocking. So I was just wondering, is there anything that you've been seeing at any of your FDM customers at this point.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, you do hear that from time to time over the years, but I don't think that ever happens. And I think the retailers are as focused on working capital as anybody else. So I think they run a pretty tight ship. So it's unusual to have a situation w
componenttext: No. I mean, you do hear that from time to time over the years, but I don't think that ever happens. And I think the retailers are as focused on working capital as anybody else. So I think they run a pretty tight ship. So it's unusual to have a situation where a retailer is overstocked and they're cutting back on their inventories.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question, I know you mentioned TROJAN before. Just been seeing some of these articles out there talking about millennials don't like condoms. So I was just wondering how do you respond to that and in terms of growing that business
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question, I know you mentioned TROJAN before. Just been seeing some of these articles out there talking about millennials don't like condoms. So I was just wondering how do you respond to that and in terms of growing that business and what do you see on your end?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always going to be a certain percent of the population that doesn't enjoy sex with a condom. But that's been a great business for a long period of time. We got a 75% share. And being the big dog in the category, it's up to us to continue to
componenttext: Well, there's always going to be a certain percent of the population that doesn't enjoy sex with a condom. But that's been a great business for a long period of time. We got a 75% share. And being the big dog in the category, it's up to us to continue to promote safe sex and compliance.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Olivia Tong of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Olivia Tong of Bank of America.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in Q4, you're looking for a 1% to 2% organic sales growth. So obviously, implied in that guidance is the potential that there could be acceleration from Q3. So can you talk about what gives you confidence in seeing that potential acceleration? Are ther
componenttext: So in Q4, you're looking for a 1% to 2% organic sales growth. So obviously, implied in that guidance is the potential that there could be acceleration from Q3. So can you talk about what gives you confidence in seeing that potential acceleration? Are there incremental programs going in place? Obviously, you've got a little bit of step down in comps, but that didn't quite help that much in Q3. So can we talk through that first please?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's a couple of things. Number one, we don't have the tactical couponing on OxiClean to the same degree that we did in Q3. We don't have the impact to the Orajel product returns/recall. On a positive note, our vitamin business and our laundry
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's a couple of things. Number one, we don't have the tactical couponing on OxiClean to the same degree that we did in Q3. We don't have the impact to the Orajel product returns/recall. On a positive note, our vitamin business and our laundry business has some promotions in Q4, but some of them were in Q3 a year ago. So we feel pretty good about the 2.5% that we called for the Consumer Domestic division. That's probably where your head's around.

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then just on the dry shampoo, you guys have talked a little bit about the $300 million opportunity if you can get to the U.K. level. So can you talk about the similarities you see between the 2 markets? And then how much of that growth that y
componenttext: Perfect. And then just on the dry shampoo, you guys have talked a little bit about the $300 million opportunity if you can get to the U.K. level. So can you talk about the similarities you see between the 2 markets? And then how much of that growth that you've seen so far is new distribution versus the underlying strength within the category? And if it does continue to grow at these levels, what about the competitive threat from others entering the category and potentially chipping away at your share?

headline: Church & Dwight Co. Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. So here's a way to think about it. There are about 60 million people in the U.K. And in U.S. dollars, the consumption of dry shampoo is about $60 million. So when we look at the U.S., we say, hey, we still got 335 million people in the
componenttext: Yes, good question. So here's a way to think about it. There are about 60 million people in the U.K. And in U.S. dollars, the consumption of dry shampoo is about $60 million. So when we look at the U.S., we say, hey, we still got 335 million people in the U.S. where we, too, have similar use [ph] consumption in the U.S., you'd have a $300 million category. So it is as simple as that. As far as where is the growth coming from, it's not simply -- it is new distribution, but it's higher consumption. The category continues to grow. And the good news for us is that the category is growing rapidly. And our share keeps expanding. So our share expanded from Q2 to Q3 in a category that's growing rapidly. And what we have going for us is that Batiste is a European brand, number one. And number two, its efficacy is far better than anything else that's on the market. So it's really product performance is what's winning. So people who have not used our product and then switch to Batiste, they don't go back. So it's -- we're not concerned about other entrants. There are a lot of people in there already, right? Not Your Mother's, TRESemm√©, et cetera. So there's plenty of big dogs in the category. So we certainly like our chances. We're #1 dry shampoo globally, not just in the U.S.

componenttext: Yes, that's a hard one to answer. I wouldn't say I can make any sweeping comment about multiples going up or down. As you know, we are an acquisitive company, so anything that is for sale in CPG, 99 out of 100 times, we will get the book. But I wouldn't say that the market has peeled off or gotten any worse.

componenttext: No, that's a good question. So it's not a function of losing share. It's entirely due to demand. The interesting thing about that business is that once a dairy farm starts using your product, and particularly, the ARM & HAMMER. So one of the products we sell under the ARM & HAMMER name is -- and it creates a lot of -- there's a lot of weight that goes with that. So once you're with the producer, they're going to stick with you. So it's not switching or share. It's just purely demand.

And then the second question is just thinking about the international business. What's the -- like the vision and the strategy on that business? I mean, are you going to take kind of like a Clorox approach and just focus on a couple of countries? Or do you believe that you have some more whitespace opportunity to expand your footprint?

componenttext: Yes, we'll stick to international one, first. So we have a business in Mexico and Brazil. So we'd like to go where the people are, right? So there's over 100 million people in Mexico, and there's 200 million in Brazil. So those would be a focus for us. And then there are countries we're not in like Germany for example, which is the largest, strongest economy in Europe. So longer term, we'd say, yes, that's a place we'd want to be in. And then export is one that is just a fountain for us, because we have found that our products do travel well, and we have built an export team with great leadership there, and we think the sky's the limit with respect to driving our product internationally. So I think that's sort of the view with respect to international, Nik. That's why we're so positive about it. Your front-end question was, are we seen more asks on the part of the retailers?
